Chapter 101 - CODIFICATION; ADOPTING ORDINANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Chapter 101 contains provisions of Adopting Ordinance 58-134, passed October 6, 1958 (as amended), which approved and adopted the original Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958. 
Cross reference- Effective date of ordinances-see CHTR. Art. II, 14. Publication and certification of ordinances in book form-see Ohio R.C. 731.23. Certified copies received in evidence-see Ohio R.C. 731.42. 

101.01 - Revision and codification. 
    The general and permanent ordinances of the City of Bay Village are revised, rearranged, compiled, renumbered as to sections and codified in component Codes designated by odd numbers, respectively, (1) Administrative Code, (3) Traffic Code, (5) General Offenses Code, (7) Business Regulation Code, (9) Streets and Public Services Code, (11) Planning and Zoning Code, (13) Building Standards, and (17) Fire Prevention Code. 
101.02 - Adoption of codified ordinances. 
    The general and permanent ordinances of the City of Bay Village so revised, rearranged, compiled, renumbered as to sections and codified, are hereby approved and adopted and the same shall be printed and published in book form in the manner and method provided in C.O. 101.12 hereof as The Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958, and when so printed, published and assembled in complete book form and certified as correct by the Mayor and Clerk of Council, shall he admitted in evidence and accepted by the courts and all persons as to the existence, effectiveness and regularity of all enactments so published in such book form as of the effective date designated herein. 
    One copy of The Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958, upon printing and certification as to correctness thereof in such book form by the Mayor and the Clerk of Council, shall be attached to this ordinance as a part hereof and filed and retained as the permanent ordinance record of the City of Bay Village, Ohio. 
101.03 - Effective date. 
    The Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958, consisting of component Codes as hereinbefore and therein designated and all provisions thereof and hereof shall take effect and be in force at, on and after 12:01 a. m., Eastern Standard Time, November 1, 1958. 
101.04 - Other amendments and supplements. 
    The Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958, may be amended or supplemented at any time and, when any amendment or supplement is adopted on such form as to indicate the intention of Council to make the same a part thereof, such amendment or supplement shall be incorporated in, and deemed a part of, the Codified Ordinances, so that a reference to the Codified Ordinances shall be understood and construed as including The Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958, and any and all such amendments and supplements. 
101.05 - Form of amendment or supplement. 
    All amendments and supplements enacted as a part of the Codified Ordinances shall be integrated therewith by following the form of arrangement and plan hereby adopted. Each Code shall be subdivided into titles; each title shall be subdivided into chapters; and each chapter shall be subdivided into sections which shall be numbered in accordance with the numbering system adopted by the Bureau of Code Revision of Ohio, established by the 96th General Assembly, for the Ohio Revised Code, as may be adaptable to the requirements of the City of Bay Village. The numbering of all sections except the penalty sections shall be consecutive within each chapter commencing with the first section of Chapter 101, which shall be numbered 101.01, the first "1" signifying Code 1, the two figures "01" before the decimal signifying the Chapter within the Code, and the two figures "01" after the decimal signifying the first section in Chapter 101 of the Code. Penalty sections shall be designated "99" and shall be the last section of the chapter. 
101.06 - How known and cited. 
    This Adopting Ordinance, The Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958, hereby adopted, and any and all amendments or supplements which may be adopted as hereinbefore provided, as any such may exist from time to time, shall be known and referred to as the Codified Ordinances; any component Code of the Codified Ordinances shall be known and referred to either as "the Code," "this Code," "component Code" or as designated in C.O. 101.01 hereof; and sections of the Codified Ordinances may be referred to and cited in the form "C.O." as may be applicable and appropriate to any section. 
101.07 - Master copies. 
    The Clerk of Council, in addition to the book form copy to be attached hereto pursuant to C.O. 101.02 hereof, shall keep one master copy in book form and, in connection therewith or attached thereto in such form and manner as he may determine to be most easily available for ready reference, one copy of all amendments and supplements bearing such Code, title, chapter or section designation as may be proper. If in doubt as to such designation, the Clerk of Council shall be guided by the advice of the Director of Law. 
101.08 - Interpretation. 
    In the construction of the Codified Ordinances, the following rules shall control, excepting those inconsistent with the manifest intent of Council as disclosed in a particular provision, section or Code: 
(1)  Calendar-Computation of time . The terms "month" and "year" shall mean the calendar month or year. The time expressed in days within which an act is to be done or a period is to expire shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day except if the last be Sunday it shall be excluded. If time is expressed in hours the whole of Sunday shall be excluded. 
(2)  City or municipality . The words "City" or "Municipality" mean the City of Bay Village, Ohio. 
(3)  Conjunctions . "And" shall include "or" and "or" shall include "and," if the sense so requires. 
(4)  Council . The word "Council" means the Council of the City of Bay Village, Ohio. 
(5)  County . The word "County" means Cuyahoga County, Ohio. 
(6)  Gender . Words importing the masculine shall extend and be applied to the feminine and neuter genders. 
(7)  General rule. Excepting as otherwise provided in this section, words and phrases shall be construed according to the common usage of language; provided, however, that technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a special meaning in the law, shall be construed according to such technical or special meaning. 
    Whenever in the Codified Ordinances authority is given to an officer or an act is required to be performed, such authority may be exercised and such act may be performed, at the instance of such officer, by a deputy or subordinate unless contrary to law or to the clear intent of any such particular provision. 
(8)  Joint authority . Words giving authority to a Board, Commission or to three or more City officers or employees or other persons shall be construed as giving authority to a majority thereof unless otherwise specifically provided. 
(9)  Number . Words in the plural shall include the singular and in the singular shall include the plural number. 
(10)  Owner . The word "owner" when applied to property shall include any part-owner, joint owner or tenant in common, of the whole or any part of such property provided however, that where service of notices of any type whatsoever is required to be made upon the "owner" of property, such service shall be deemed valid when served upon the person indicated as the owner by the land records of Cuyahoga County or by any other public records. 
(11)  Person . The word "person" shall extend to and be applied to associations, clubs, corporations, firms and partnerships, as well as to individuals. 
(12)  Premises . The word "premises" when used as applicable to property shall extend to and include land and buildings. 
(13)  Public authority. The term "public authority" shall extend to and include the Board of Education of the City, the City, the County Commissioners, the State of Ohio, the United States of America, and any duly authorized public official. 
(14)  Property . The word "property" shall include real and personal, and any mixed and lesser estates or interests therein; the words "personal property" shall include every kind of property except real property; and the words "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
(15)  Reasonable time. In all cases where provision is made for an act to be done or notice to be given within a reasonable time, it shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such act or giving of such notice. 
(16)  Safety director. The title "Safety Director" shall be deemed to mean the Director of Public Safety of the City of Bay Village. 
(17)  Sidewalk . The term "sidewalk" shall mean that portion of the street, located between the paved portion of the street and the parallel property line intended for use by pedestrians. 
(18)  State . The words "the State" or "this State" shall be construed to mean the State of Ohio. 
(19)  Street . The word "street" shall be construed to include alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, streets and other public ways in the City. 
(20)  Tenant or occupant . The words "tenant" or "occupant" as applied to a building or land shall extend and be applied to any person holding a written or oral lease of or who occupies the whole or any part of a building or land, alone or with others. 
(21)  Tenses . The use of any verb in the present tense shall include the future. 
101.09 - Separability. 
    Each section and each part of each section of the Codified Ordinances is hereby declared to be an independent section or part of a section and, notwithstanding any other evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared to be the controlling legislative intent that if any such section or part of a section, or any provision thereof, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is held to be invalid, the remaining sections or parts of sections and the application of such provision to any other person or circumstances, other than those as to which it is held invalid, shall not be affected thereby, and it is hereby declared to be the legislative intent that the Codified Ordinances would have been adopted independently of such section, sections or parts of a section so held to be invalid. 
101.10 - Repeal of prior ordinances. 
    All ordinances and parts of ordinances enacted prior to July 1, 1958 which are incorporated in The Codified Ordinances of Bay Village, Ohio, 1958, saving and accepting Zoning Ordinance 54-42 enacted April 29, 1954, as amended from time to time, are hereby repealed as of the effective date hereof as follows:

101.11 - Prior ordinances not affected by repeal. 
    The repeal of ordinances as provided in C.O. 101.10 shall not affect: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the first day of November, 1958; 
(2)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or to the City, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City, or any evidence of the City's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the City; 
(3)  The administrative ordinances or resolutions of the Council not in conflict or inconsistent with the provisions of the Codified Ordinances; 
(4)  Any right or franchise conferred by any ordinance or resolution of the Council on any person or corporation; 
(5)  Any ordinance naming, relocating or vacating any street or public way; 
(6)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes, assessments, or charges; 
(7)  Any salary ordinance; 
(8)  Any prosecution, suit or other proceeding pending, or any judgment rendered on or prior to October 31, 1958; and 
(9)  Any ordinance which may be adopted by Council after the thirtieth day of June, 1958. 
101.12 - Publication. 
    The Clerk of Council shall cause each component code to be printed in separate pamphlet or book form, and thereupon assemble all such component codes into not less than 200 complete books as the Codified Ordinances of the City of Bay Village, Ohio, for certification as correct by the Mayor and the Clerk of Council. The Clerk of Council shall attach one such complete book to the original manuscript copy of this adopting ordinance as provided in Section 101.02. 
    The Clerk of Council shall deliver, without cost, one complete book to the Mayor and one to each member of Council which shall remain the property of the Mayor and Councilmen at the expiration of their terms of office, provided however, should such person succeed himself in office he shall not be entitled to additional copies of the book. He shall further deliver, at no cost, one to each Judge and one to the Clerk of the Rocky River Municipal Court, one to the Prosecutor and three copies to the Director of Law, only two copies of which need to be returned to the Clerk by the Director of Law upon his removal or resignation. He shall further deliver, at no cost, one copy to the Assistant to the Law Director, one copy to the head of each department and division of the City, except the Department of Building Engineering and Inspection which shall receive three copies, the Police Division to which shall be delivered three copies (one for the use of the Chief of Police, one to remain in the Police Station at all times and one which may be circulated among the members of the Police Division for the purpose of study and review) and three copies to the Division of Fire. He shall further deliver, without cost, two copies to the library maintained by the Bay Village High School, one copy to the Middle School Library, one copy to the Board of Education and one copy to the Cuyahoga County Library for use in the branch maintained in this City. The Clerk is further directed to supply the Planning Commission with five copies, the Board of Zoning Appeals with seven copies, the Review Committee with one copy, the Civil Service Commission with three copies and the receptionist with one copy, which copies are to be used by such persons during their service and are not to be the personal copies of such persons. One copy each is to be delivered to: the Regional Planning Commission, Secretary of State, Deputy Inspector of Municipalities, County Auditor, Cuyahoga County Mayors and Managers Association, Cleveland State University Institute of Urban Studies, Cleveland Law Library Association, Ohio State University College of Law, Municipal Reference Library, League of Women Voters, Ohio Municipal League and Squire, Sanders & Dempsey. Two copies are to be delivered to the Cuyahoga County Juvenile Court. 
    The Clerk of Council shall sell complete books at $100.00 a copy. Replacement pages, at such time as Council authorizes the same, shall be sold at $25.00 a set. No separate components of the Codified Ordinances shall be sold separately, but the books shall be sold as complete Codes only. The Clerk shall maintain a file of the name and address of each person to whom a Code is delivered or sold. 
    One copy shall be kept in the Clerk's office at all times for the use of the members of City boards and commissions. 
    The Clerk of Council shall have authority to exchange copies of the Codified Ordinances with other cities extending like courtesy to the City upon written authorization by the Mayor. 
    The Clerk of Council shall prepare and distribute periodically, the amendments and supplements to the Codified Ordinances. 
(Ord. 86-8. Passed 1-20-86.) 
101.121 - Distribution of codified ordinances copies. 
    In addition to the provisions for the distribution of Codified Ordinances as set forth in C.O. 101.12, the Clerk is hereby authorized and directed to distribute copies of Codified Ordinances to such persons as the Mayor may, in writing, designate, provided, however not less than ten copies shall be retained for disposition by Council. 
(Ord. 88-124. Passed 9-6-88.) 
101.13 - Public notice. 
    The Clerk of Council shall cause to be posted in the manner required by law a notice of the enactment of this ordinance containing the title hereof and a summary of the new matter contained in the codification. 
101.99 - General penalty. 
    Whenever in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the City any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or when in such Codified Ordinances or other ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violator of any such provision shall be fined not exceeding $100.00. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day continued. 
Chapter 103 - STANDARDS AND INSIGNIA[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- State standard of time-see Ohio R.C. 1.04. 

103.01 - Standard of time. 
    The standard of time throughout the City shall be the same as the official time of the City of Cleveland, Ohio. 
103.02 - Governs proceedings. 
    The Municipal offices and legal proceedings of the City shall be regulated by such standard of time, and when by ordinance, resolution or action of any Municipal officer or body an act must be performed at or within a prescribed time it shall be so performed according to such standard of time. 
103.03 - Public clocks. 
    When a clock or other timepiece is in or upon a public building maintained at the expense of the City, the board, commission, Council, officer or other person having control and charge of such building shall have such clock or other timepiece set and run according to the standard of time as provided herein. 
103.04 - Official tree. 
    The Flowering Crab (Malus Echtermeyer) is adopted as the official tree of the City. 
(Ord. 59-62. Passed 6-1-59.) 
103.05 - Acceptance of donations and gifts. 
(a)  All offers of property and/or services to be donated to the City having a value in excess of $100.00 shall be submitted to Council by the donor or forwarded to Council by the boards or agencies receiving such offer for acceptance by Council on behalf of the City. 
(b)  Satisfactory assurance must be received by Council that the donor has the power to make such a donation and that, if property is involved, it is fully paid for or satisfactory arrangements have been made for payment. 
(Ord. 66-161. Passed 2-20-67.) 
103.06 - Official flag. 
(a)  The City does hereby officially declare that there will be an official flag for the City. 
(b)  The drawing of the flag shall be used to design and make the official flag of the City, which flag shall fly and be displayed on holidays and official functions of the City. 
(Ord. 70-92. Passed 5-18-70.) 
103.07 - Official bush. 
    The Bayberry Bush (Myrica pennsylvanica) is adopted as the official bush of the City and shall be known as the "Bay Berry Bush." 
(Ord. 85-132. Passed 10-7-85.) 
103.08 - Official bicentennial flag. 
    Council hereby approves the design by Chairman Tadych as the official bicentennial flag and looks forward to said flag being displayed throughout the year and during the City's bicentennial celebration festivities. 
(Res. 10-39. Passed 4-19-10.) 
Chapter 105 - WARDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Division into wards-see Ohio R.C. 731.06. Voting precincts-see Ohio R.C. 3501.18. 

105.01 - Four wards established. 
(a)  Ward 1. Ward 1 shall contain all that territory bounded and described as follows: 
Bounded on the north by Lake Erie; bounded on the east by the corporation line of the City; bounded on the south by the corporation line of the City; and bounded on the west by the center line of Parkside Drive. 
(b)  Ward 2. Ward 2 shall contain all that territory bounded and described as follows: 
Bounded on the north by Lake Erie; bounded on the east by the center line of Parkside Drive, bounded on the south by the corporation line of the City; and bounded on the west by the westerly property line of Cahoon Memorial Park, and continuing south along the center line of Sutcliffe Drive and its prolongation to the southerly corporation line of the City. 
(c)  Ward 3. Ward 3 shall contain all that territory bounded and described as follows: 
Bounded on the north by Lake Erie; bounded on the west by a line beginning at a point in Lake Erie between the properties of Permanent Parcel No. 201-6-5 and Permanent Parcel No. 201-6-6 to the center line of Saddler Road, continuing southerly along the center line of Saddler Road to its intersection with the center line of Winsor Drive, thence westerly along the center line of Winsor Drive to its intersection with Saddler Road, thence southerly along the center line of Saddler Road to its intersection with the center line of Ednil Drive, thence easterly along the center line of Ednil Drive to its intersection with the center line of Saddler Road, thence southerly along the center line of Saddler Road to its intersection with the center line of Wolf Road, thence easterly along the center line of Wolf Road to its intersection with the northerly prolongation of the easterly line of the Board of Education property (Westerly School site), thence southerly along the easterly line of the Board of Education property, and its northerly prolongation, to the center line of Porter Creek, thence in a general easterly direction following the center line of Porter Creek to the rear property lot lines between Wildbrook Drive and Bassett Road, thence southerly along the predominant such rear lot lines, and its southerly prolongation, to the southerly corporation line of the City; bounded on the south by the southerly corporation line of the City; and bounded on the east by the westerly property line of Cahoon Memorial Park, and continuing southerly along the center line of Sutcliffe Drive and its prolongation to the southerly corporation line of the City. 
(d)  Ward 4. Ward 4 shall contain all that territory bounded and described as follows: 
Bounded on the north by Lake Erie; bounded on the east by a line beginning at a point in Lake Erie between the properties of Permanent Parcel No. 201-6-5 and Permanent Parcel No. 201-6-6 to the center line of Saddler Road, continuing southerly along the center line of Saddler Road to its intersection with the center line of Winsor Drive, thence westerly along the center line of Winsor Drive to its intersection with Saddler Road, thence southerly along the center line of Saddler Road to its intersection with the center line of Ednil Drive, thence easterly along the center line of Ednil Drive to its intersection with the center line of Saddler Road, thence southerly along the center line of Saddler Road to its intersection with the center line of Wolf Road, thence easterly along the center line of Wolf Road to its intersection with the northerly prolongation of the easterly line of the Board of Education property (Westerly School site), thence southerly along the easterly line of the Board of Education property, and its northerly prolongation, to the center line of Porter Creek, thence in a general easterly direction following the center line of Porter Creek to the rear property lot lines between Wildbrook Drive and Bassett Road, thence southerly along the predominant such rear lot lines, and its southerly prolongation, to the southerly corporation line of the City; bounded on the south by the southerly corporation line of the City; and bounded on the west by the westerly corporation line of the City. 
(Ord. 76-181. Passed 2-7-77.) 
Chapter 107 - OPEN MEETINGS 

107.01 - Public meetings. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided in the Codified Ordinances, all meetings of Council, Board of Zoning Appeals, Planning Commission, Recreation Commission, Assessment Equalization Boards, and other similar public bodies of the City as may be appointed from time to time, and any committees of the above comprised of the members of such public bodies where such committees (1) are comprised of a majority of the members of the main public body; or (2) are decision making committees, shall be open to the public unless an executive session is expressly authorized under the appropriate provision of state law. 
(b)  Nothing herein contained shall mandate that any public body permit public participation in said meetings unless specifically required by the provisions of the Charter or Codified Ordinances. (Ord. 75-178. Passed 12-29-75.) 
107.02 - Executive session. 
    The members of a public body may hold an executive session only at a regular, special or committee meeting upon approval of a motion by a majority of a quorum for the sole purpose of the consideration of any of the following matters: 
(a)  Unless the public employee, official, licensee, or regulated individual requests a public hearing, to consider the appointment, employment, dismissal, discipline, promotion, demotion, or compensation of a public employee or official, licensee, or regulated individual. Except as otherwise provided by law, no public body shall hold an executive session for the discipline of an elected official for conduct related to the performance of his official duties or for his removal from office. 
(b)  To consider the purchase of property for public purposes, or for the sale of property at competitive bidding, if premature disclosure of information would give an unfair competitive or bargaining advantage to a person whose personal, private interest is adverse to the general public interest. No member shall use this division as a subterfuge for providing covert information to prospective buyers or sellers. A purchase or sale of public property is void if the seller or buyer of the public property has received covert information from a member that has not been disclosed to the general public in sufficient time for other prospective buyers and sellers to prepare and submit offers. 
(c)  If the minutes of the public body show that all meetings and deliberations of the public body have been conducted in compliance with this section, any instrument executed by the public body purporting to convey, lease, or otherwise dispose of any right, title, or interest in any public property shall be conclusively presumed to have been executed in compliance with this section insofar as title or other interest of any bona fide purchasers, lessees, or transferees of the property is concerned. 
(d)  Conferences with an attorney for the public body, concerning disputes involving the public body that are the subject of pending or imminent court action. 
(e)  Preparing for, conducting or reviewing negotiations or bargaining sessions with public employees concerning their compensation or other terms and conditions of their employment. 
(f)  Matters required to be kept confidential by federal law or rules or state statutes. 
(g)  Specialized details of security arrangements where disclosure of the matters discussed might reveal information that could be used for the purpose of committing, or avoiding prosecution for, a violation of the law. 
(Ord. 88-103. Passed 7-18-88.) 
107.03 - Public notification. 
(a)  Regular meetings. The time and place of all regular meetings of public bodies designated in Section 107.01 of this Code, hereof shall be noted in a calendar of annual meetings. This calendar shall be posted in the office of the Clerk of Council at City Hall, and those posting places established in Section 113.01 of this Code, not later than the second day preceding the day of the first regular meeting of the calendar year of that public body. 
(b)  Special meetings. Notification of any special meeting of the public bodies designated in Section 107.01 of this Code, shall be given to any news media requesting such notification 24 hours prior to the time of such meetings. This notification shall include the time, place, and purpose of the special meeting. In addition, such notice shall also be posted in the office of the Clerk of Council at City Hall, and those posting places established in Section 113.01 of the Codified Ordinances as soon as practicable after the scheduling of such meeting. 
(c)  Emergency meetings. In the event of an emergency meeting, the persons calling such meeting, or any one or more of such persons, or the Clerk or secretary on their behalf, shall immediately give notice of such emergency meeting to the news media which have requested notice of time, place and purpose of the emergency meeting. 
(Ord. 75-178. Passed 12-29-75.) 
107.04 - Personal notification. 
(a)  Any person may, upon written request, and as provided herein, obtain reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which any special type of public business is scheduled to be discussed. 
(b)  To obtain the notice provided in paragraph (a), such persons are required to file a written request with the appropriate Clerk or secretary specifying: Person's name, address and telephone number at or through which the person can be reached during and outside of business hours, the specific type of public business the discussion of which the person is requesting advanced notification, the public body that is the subject of such request, and the number of calendar months (not to exceed 12 months) which the request covers. Such request may be cancelled by request of such person to the Clerk or Secretary, 
(c)  Each request provided for in paragraph (b) hereof must be accompanied by cash, check, or money order payable to the City of Bay Village in the amount of $1.00 for each month covered by the request. 
(Ord. 75-178. Passed 12-29-75.) 
107.05 - Minutes of meetings. 
    Minutes of regular and special meetings of public bodies set forth in Section 107.01 hereof shall promptly be recorded in writing and open to the public for inspection. Minutes of executive sessions of public bodies need only reflect the general subject matter of discussion in such executive session. 
(Ord. 75-178. Passed 12-29-75.) 
Title Three - LEGISLATIVE 
Chapter 111 Council 
Chapter 113 Ordinances and Resolutions 
Chapter 115 Zoning and Land Development Ordinances 
Chapter 111 - COUNCIL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Charter provisions-see CHTR. Art. II. State law provisions-see Ohio R.C. 731.01 et seq. 

111.01 - Time and place of meetings. 
    Regular meetings of the Council shall be held in the City Hall on the first and third Mondays of each and every month at 8:00 p.m. unless otherwise ordered by the Council. Should such date be a holiday, the regular meeting shall be held on the next succeeding business day. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.02 - Adjourning meetings; notice. 
    Any regular meeting may be adjourned to any later date prior to the date of the next regular meeting. If the time for reassembly is more than 24 hours after the time of adjournment, any member of Council, or the Mayor, absent from the meeting which was adjourned shall be notified of such adjournment by written notice served personally or left at his regular place of residence at least six hours prior to the hour of reassembly of such adjourned meeting. 
(Ord. 65-148. Passed 12-6-65.) 
111.03 - Officers of council. 
    The officers of the Council shall be: 
(a)  The President of Council, who shall have the powers, duties, obligations and rights granted by the Charter of the City and, in addition, he shall appoint all committees and serve as an ex-officio member of each. 
(b)  The Vice-President, who shall have all the powers, duties, functions and right of any other member of Council and, in addition thereto, shall, in the absence of the President, preside at all meetings of the Council. The Vice President of Council shall be selected by a majority vote of the members of Council from among its members at its first or second meeting in January of each even-numbered year. He shall serve for a term of two years or for such shorter period of time as he may be a Councilman. Any vacancy for an unexpired term shall be filled in the same manner as provided herein for the original selection. 
(c)  The Clerk of Council, who shall attend all regular and special meetings of Council; keep the journal of the Council; prepare its minutes and be the custodian of all resolutions, ordinances, motions, and other action passed or adopted by the Council, and all papers or other documents kept by the Council; shall serve or cause to be served all notices required by law to be served; shall post or publish or cause to be posted or published all ordinances, resolutions and action of the Council required to be published or posted; and shall perform such other and further duties as may be imposed by a Clerk of Council or as may be requested by the Council. The Clerk shall furnish the Mayor and each member of Council a copy of the minutes of any Council meeting within one week after the date of such meeting and shall at the same time furnish the Mayor and each member of Council a current compilation of matters pending before each Council committee. It shall be the duty of the Clerk to prepare, with the advice of the President of Council, an agenda of the business proposed to be transacted at any Council meeting and to cause a copy thereof to be delivered to each member of Council and the Mayor not later than 48 hours before the scheduled time for the meeting. No matter not included on the agenda or otherwise called to the attention of all members of Council at least 24 hours before the meeting shall be submitted to Council for final action. The Clerk of Council shall be selected by a majority of the members of Council at its first or second meeting in January of each even numbered year and the Clerk shall serve during the pleasure of Council. If the Clerk is unable to attend any meeting, an Acting Clerk of Council shall be designated by the President, or in his absence, by the presiding member of Council. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.04 - President pro-tem. 
    In the absence of the President and the Vice-President the Council shall select one of its members as President pro-tem. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.05 - Regular committees. 
    Regular committees of Council shall be selected by the President by the second meeting of January in each even-numbered year or as soon thereafter as convenient and each such committee shall be composed of three Councilmen. Whenever feasible the committees shall be so organized that the three Councilmen named to any one committee shall serve together on two or more other committees so as to facilitate committee meetings. Regular committees shall include: 
(a)  Environment, Safety, and Community Services. 
(b)  Public Improvements, Streets, Sewers, and Drainage. 
(c)  Finance and Claims. 
(d)  Planning, Zoning and Public Grounds and Buildings. 
(e)  Recreation and Park Improvements. 
(f)  Services, Utilities and Equipment. 
    Committee assignments may be changed at any time thereafter, or a vacancy filled, by the president with the approval of a majority of Council. Council may at any time by majority vote of members of Council reorganize any or all committees by designating the Chairman and the members of such committee or committees. 
(Ord. 98-02. Passed 1-12-98.) 
111.06 - Special committees. 
    The President may at any regular Council meeting, and at any other time as directed by Council, appoint special committees and the chairmen thereof. Committee assignments may be changed at any time thereafter, or a vacancy filled, by the President with the approval of a majority of Council. Council may at any time by majority vote reorganize any or all committees by designating the Chairman and the members of such committee. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.07 - Standing committees. 
    Standing committees of Council shall meet not later than the Wednesday immediately preceding a regular Council meeting at such place as shall be agreed upon by the committee. Special committees shall meet at the call of the Chairman at such place as shall be agreeable to the committee. Any committee chairman having business to come before the Council shall by 10:00 p.m. of the Thursday immediately prior to the meeting of Council notify the President of the nature of the business so that such can be included on the agenda for the Council meeting. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.08 - Election of members to boards. 
    Council shall at the organizational meeting in January of each even-numbered year select from among its members by a majority vote of the members of Council a member of the Planning Commission and a member of the Recreation Commission. In the event any such person chosen shall cease to be a Councilman or resign from the post to which selected by Council, the vacancy for the unexpired term shall be filled by Council in the same manner as provided herein for the original selection. 
(Ord. 74-39. Passed 3-18-74.) 
111.09 - Procedure for requests for action by council. 
    Any request by anyone other than the Mayor or a member of Council calling for final action by Council at a designated meeting shall be communicated to the President of Council not later than 8:00 p.m. of the fourth day preceding such Council meeting, which request shall outline the factual basis for and the nature of the Council action sought. The President of Council shall promptly refer such request to the proper committee for study and recommendation. If any such request is made after such time, the President shall refer the request to the proper committee for report and recommendation not later than the next subsequent Council meeting. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.10 - Procedure for ordinances and resolutions. 
    No ordinance or resolution shall be passed unless a written copy thereof is before the Council. A copy of the proposed ordinance or resolution shall be submitted to each Councilman at least 24 hours before any meeting of Council at which action on such ordinance or resolution is contemplated. It shall be in order to amend any ordinance or resolution at any time before passage but such amendment must be in writing before it shall be voted on. No second shall be required for any Council action. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.11 - Order of speaking. 
    No member shall speak more than once upon any matter except to answer a question, until every member of Council desiring to speak thereon shall have had an opportunity to speak. No member shall interrupt a speaker except to call him to order. If any member shall violate any rule of the Council the presiding officer or any member may immediately cease speaking until the question of order shall be decided. All questions of order shall be decided by the presiding officer subject to any appeal to the Council. All improper conduct is prohibited in the Council Chamber during the meeting of the Council. No person not a member of the Council shall be allowed to address the Council or any member thereof without the consent of the presiding officer, subject to an appeal to the Council. No such person shall be permitted to speak for a period in excess of ten minutes. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.12 - Order of precedence for motions. 
    When a resolution, ordinance or motion is before the Council or under debate, no motion shall be received except the following: 
(a)  To adjourn; 
(b)  To lay on the table; 
(c)  For the previous question; 
(d)  To postpone to a certain day; 
(e)  To return to committee; 
(f)  To amend; 
(g)  To postpone indefinitely. 
    These motions shall have precedence in the order in which they are named. 
    The above motions shall always be in order until the Clerk has started the call of the roll. A motion to adjourn, to lay on the table, or for the previous question shall be decided without debate. When a motion is made it shall be restated by the President before any debate shall be in order. Any motion may be withdrawn by the mover thereof at any time before vote. Robert's Rules of Order shall govern in all cases not covered by the laws of Ohio, the Charter of the City or these rules. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.13 - Reconsideration of motion. 
    Any member who voted with the prevailing side on any question may move for a reconsideration thereof, provided that the motion to reconsider is not made later than prior to the adjournment of the next regular meeting after such action was taken. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.14 - Order of business. 
    The business of the regular meetings of Council shall be transacted in the following order: 
(a)  Roll call. 
(b)  Reading minutes of previous meetings. 
(c)  Reports from Mayor and department heads. 
(d)  Communications. 
(e)  Requests from citizens in the audience. 
(f)  Reports of committees and Council representatives to administrative boards. 
(g)  Miscellaneous business. 
(h)  Adjournment. 
(Ord. 76-157. Passed 11-1-76.) 
111.15 - Confirmation of appointments. 
    Each appointment by the Mayor subject to confirmation by the Council shall be announced at a regular or special meeting of Council. Action for confirmation of such appointment shall, thereafter, be taken at the next regular meeting of Council. Confirmation must be by majority vote of the members of Council. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
111.16 - Rules subject to amendment. 
    These rules are intended to supplement the laws of the State of Ohio and the provisions of the Charter of the City governing the procedure of Council. Any of these rules may be amended, altered or new rules adopted at any regular or special meeting of Council, by a vote of two-thirds of the members of Council. These rules or any of them may be suspended at any regular or special meeting of the Council by a vote of two-thirds of the members of Council. 
(Ord. 57-40. Passed 4-5-57.) 
Chapter 113 - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Charter provisions-see CHTR. Art. II,  14, 15. State law provisions-see Ohio R.C. 731.17 et seq. Adopting ordinance-see ADM. Ch. 101. Council procedure-see ADM. 111.10. 

113.01 - Posting legislation. 
    Ordinances and resolutions adopted by Council shall be posted for 15 days at the following places: 
(a)  The City Hall. 
(b)  The Bay Village Public Library, located at the intersection of Cahoon and West Oakland Roads. 
(c)  The Bay Village Web Site www.cityofbayvillage.com. 
(Ord. 03-03. Passed 1-21-03.) 
113.02 - Notice to property owners. 
    Upon the passage by Council of any resolution or ordinance declaring it necessary to make any public improvement, any portion of which it is contemplated will be assessed, the Clerk of Council, at least five days prior to Council meeting at which voting is scheduled on the question of proceeding with the improvement, shall give notice by regular mail to each property owner whose property is in the area to be assessed. 
    The notice shall state the fact of the passage of the resolution or ordinance of necessity, and the date and time of the Council meeting to consider the question of whether or not to proceed with the contemplated improvement. Such notice shall be sufficient if addressed to the last known address of the property owner available on City records. 
    No such notice by mail need be given however where notice to residents by personal service, residence service or by certified or regular mail is otherwise required by statute or ordinance. The failure of the Clerk of Council to mail the notice required by this section, or the failure of any property owner to receive such notice shall not affect the regularity or validity of any improvement proceedings. 
(Ord. 61-219. Passed 11-20-61.) 
Chapter 115 - ZONING AND LAND DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning and platting regulations-see Part Eleven-PLANNING AND ZONING CODE. 

115.01 - Conformity. 
    Every ordinance referring to zoning, rezoning or any other regulation or ordinance controlling the use or development of land located within the City shall be subject to the practices and procedures contained in this chapter. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58.) 
115.02 - Contents of applications. 
(a)  Duplicate written applications for land development or use, zoning or rezoning shall be filed with the City Planning Commission. The applications shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the applicant. If the applicant is different from the owner, a written authorization from the owner consenting to the application must be filed. 
(2)  A description of the property involved, if any. The description shall be deemed adequate if it refers to the Cuyahoga County Auditor's permanent parcel numbers. 
(3)  Scale drawing showing dimensions of the land involved together with its relationship to the two closest public streets and the land immediately surrounding the subject land. 
(4)  A concise request for the action sought. 
(b)  In addition, whoever petitions or requests that real property be rezoned to a less restrictive use classification shall: 
(1)  Set forth in the petition or request a detailed description of the specific use to which the real property in question shall be put following successful completion of such rezoning; and 
(2)  Shall present such petition or request, in writing, in open Planning Commission meeting and in open Council meeting to be duly recorded in the minutes of the Planning Commission and Council: and 
(3)  Secure a building permit or certificate of occupancy within a period of 12 months from and after the effective date of the rezoning. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58; amend. Ord. 75-23. Passed 5-5-75.) 
115.03 - Mayor, council, right to initiate. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to limit the right of any member of Council or the Mayor to initiate any ordinance referring to zoning, rezoning or any other regulation or ordinance controlling the use or development of land located within the City. The terms of C.O. 115.02 shall be deemed complied with when a matter is referred to the Planning Commission by Council. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58.) 
115.04 - Planning commission required to act. 
    The Planning Commission shall act on the application within 60 days from the date of its next regular meeting succeeding the date the application is filed; provided however, any matter referred to the Planning Commission by the Council shall be acted upon within 60 days from the date of referral. Failure of the Planning Commission to act within the time limits prescribed above shall be considered as though the application or referral is recommended as filed. The Planning Commission may approve the request, either in whole or in part, modify it or fail to approve it. Such action shall be upon motion passed by a majority of the members of the Planning Commission. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58.) 
115.05 - Transmittal of planning commission action to council. 
    The action or failure to act of the Planning Commission shall be transmitted to the Clerk of Council who shall place the matter on the agenda for consideration at the Council meeting next succeeding the transmittal. There shall also be filed with the Clerk of Council one copy of the items described in C.O. 115.02. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58.) 
115.06 - Council may override planning commission action. 
    Any ordinance referring to zoning, rezoning or other regulation or ordinance controlling the use or development of land which has been disapproved by action of the Planning Commission in accordance with this chapter shall require a two-thirds vote of the members of Council for adoption or modification. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58.) 
115.07 - Public hearing before council. 
    Before adopting any ordinance or regulation falling within the terms of this chapter a public hearing shall be held before the members of Council, which hearing may be held during any Council meeting or at any other time designated in the notice of hearing. Not less than ten days shall elapse between the publication of the notice and the adoption of any ordinance or resolution falling within the terms of this chapter. Final legislative action may be taken at any time following the public hearing. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58.) 
115.08 - Notice of public hearing. 
    Notice of the public hearing shall be given by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation within the City, which newspaper need not meet the requirements of Ohio Revised Code 7.12 and which newspaper may be distributed by its publisher free of charge. In addition to the newspaper publication, notice of the hearing shall be posted at the three places designated in C.O. 113.01. The notice shall be published and posted at least on the fifth day preceding the day of public hearing. 
(Ord. 14-04. Passed 2-24-14.) 
115.09 - Subdivision of land not affected. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall be deemed to affect the practices and procedures established with respect to the subdivision of land. 
(Ord. 58-131. Passed 12-1-58.)

Chapter 121 - MAYOR[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Charter provisions-see CHTR. Art. III. Run-off election for Mayor-see CHTR. Art. XI, Sec. 4. State law provisions-see Ohio R.C. 733.02 et seq. Mayor and Confidential Investigation Fund-see ADM. 125.14(d)(1), (f). Authority to limit use of water-see S. & P.S. 911.01. 

121.01 - Use of city property; permit. 
    The Mayor shall have the authority to permit any individual, group of individuals or any organization to use and occupy without compensation real property belonging to the City (excluding therefrom any property regularly rented or for the use of which a fee is regularly charged) upon a determination by the Mayor that: 
(a)  Such requested use will not interfere with the administration of City business. 
(b)  The City is adequately protected against claims that might arise out of such requested use. 
(c)  Adequate safeguards for the protection of City property are provided. 
(d)  Such requested use is for a purpose beneficial to the community and is not a commercial venture. For this purpose a fund raising activity of a service type organization shall not be considered a commercial venture. 
(e)  Such use shall be for a period of not to exceed 30 days. 
(Res. 57-58. Passed 4-17-57.) 
Editor's note- The provisions of this section shall not apply to Cahoon Memorial Park. 
121.02 - Council approval. 
    Any request for the use of City property for a period in excess of three days shall be submitted to the Council by the Mayor, together with his recommendation for approval or disapproval. In all other cases the decision of the Mayor shall be final. 
(Res. 57-58. Passed 4-17-57.) 
Chapter 123 - DEPARTMENT OF LAW[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Provisions concerning the establishment of the Department of Law and the duties of the Director may be found in the City Charter, Article IV, sections 1 and 3. Provisions concerning the City Prosecutor, enacted by ordinance, are set forth below. 
Cross reference- City Solicitors-see Ohio R.C. 733.51 et seq. Director of Law to help with designation of codification sections-see ADM. 101.07. 

123.01 - City prosecutor established. 
    Within the Department of Law there is established the office of City Prosecutor. 
(Ord. 58-31. Passed 4-21-58.) 
123.02 - Duties. 
    The duties of the City Prosecutor shall be to prosecute all cases brought before the courts having criminal jurisdiction of violation of ordinances or statutes committed within the City or any appeal therefrom, and to perform the duties, as they are applicable thereto, as required of the prosecuting attorney of the County. 
(Ord. 58-31. Passed 4-21-58.) 
123.03 - Qualification; appointment. 
    The City Prosecutor shall be an attorney at law, admitted to practice in Ohio. The City Prosecutor shall be either the Director of Law, in which case he shall also receive such compensation established for the office of City Prosecutor, or he shall be a person appointed by the Director of Law and shall serve at the pleasure of the Director of Law. 
(Ord. 68-164. Passed 12-16-68.) 
Chapter 125 - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Council by Ordinance 73-112, passed June 13, 1973, has changed the terms Auditor and Treasurer to Director of Finance in order to conform with a Charter amendment by the electors. 
Cross reference- Department established-see CHTR. Art. IV,  1. Duties of Director-see CHTR. Art. IV,  4. Charter provisions-see CHTR. Art. IX. Division of Police-see ADM. Ch. 129. 

125.01 - Title of assistant to the director of finance established. 
    Within the Department of Finance there is established the position of assistant to the Director of Finance. 
(Ord. 59-101. Passed 10-5-59.) 
125.02 - Duties. 
    The assistant to the Director of Finance shall perform such duties as are prescribed by the Director of Finance. 
(Ord. 59-101. Passed 10-5-59.) 
125.03 - Additional charges for assessments. 
    To provide for the Municipality's cost of collection and interest, there shall be added to each and every assessment or charge certified to the County Auditor for collection, other than assessments levied pursuant to Chapter 727 of the Ohio Revised Code or the sewer rental charge of the City, the sum of $10.00. Prior to the certification of any such charge or assessment to the County Auditor for collection, the person to be charged shall be given 30 days to pay the amount owning without the addition of such $10.00 charge. 
(Ord. 61-127. Passed 6-5-61.) 
125.04 - Improvement fund. 
    There is hereby established under Ohio R.C. 5705.12 and subject to the approval of the Bureau of Inspection and Supervision of Public Offices of the State of Ohio, a Public Improvement Fund. The receipts to the Fund may be transferred by Council on or before December 31 of any fiscal year, from excess receipts to the General Fund, from inheritance taxes, classified intangible taxes and undivided local government fund receipts. In addition, Council may by ordinance provide that a part or all of the proceeds from any municipal tax on income be credited directly to this Fund. The moneys in the Fund may be appropriated and expended for purchase, maintenance and repair of equipment of any department of the City and for the purchase, construction, installation, maintenance and repair of any permanent improvement to any City buildings, land or streets, pursuant to the appropriation of the Fund by Council. 
(Ord. 68-70. Passed 5-20-68.)

The moneys in the Fund may be appropriated and expended for the purchase and installation of ornamental trees requested by property owners of the City. Receipts for such Fund shall be the charges established for the cost of such trees and installation. 
(Ord. 69-143. Passed 12-22-69.) 
125.07 - Public properties replacement and repair fund. 
    There is hereby established under Ohio R.C. 5705.12 and subject to the approval of the Bureau of Inspection and Supervision of Public Offices of the State of Ohio, a Public Properties Replacement and Repair Fund. The moneys in the Fund may be appropriated and expended for the replacement or repair of any City property which has been damaged or destroyed by the acts of third parties and for which reimbursement for such damage by the third parties is expected. The receipts to the Fund shall be the amount of such damage or destruction paid to the City by anyone so causing such damage or destruction. 
(Ord. 69-152. Passed 12-22-69.)

(Ord. 03-82. Passed 6-30-03.)

Such charge shall be paid by the person requesting the certification and all such amounts collected shall be deposited and credited to the General Fund.

125.11 - Equipment replacement fund. 
    There is hereby established under Ohio R.C. 5705.12 an Equipment Replacement Fund. Such Fund is to receive the amortized value of all working equipment and/or personal property on an accumulative basis for ultimate replacement of such equipment and/or personal property. The moneys in such Equipment Replacement Fund may be appropriated from and expended for the purchase of working equipment and/or personal property for any department of the City. 
(Ord. 88-20. Passed 2-16-88.) 
125.12 - Repealed. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 97-108, adopted Dec. 15, 1997, repealed  125.12, which pertained to Police Record System Fund. 
125.13 - Repealed. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 97-108, adopted Dec. 15, 1997, repealed  125.13, which pertained to Bay Village Youth Commission Fund. 
125.14 - Confidential investigation fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created an account to be known as a Confidential Investigation Fund within the Division of Police, in the City. 
(b)  From time to time moneys will be appropriated into the Confidential Investigation Fund by Council for use under the direction of the Chief of Police, who shall be responsible for the expenditures of the same. An accounting shall be made, from time to time, of the expenditures, by the Chief to the Director, and it shall be the duty and responsibility of the Chief to petition Council for funds when needed. 
(c)  The funds in the Confidential Investigation Fund shall be expended to the following general provisions and conditions: 
(1)  The purchase of information and the entertainment of suspects and informants, who furnish or who are deemed to be qualified to furnish information of possible value of an investigative mission, constitute a proper claim for reimbursement. Investigators may claim reimbursement for meals and refreshments taken by themselves and others associated with the investigation in circumstances necessitating their doing so in conjunction with informers or contracts; however, confidential investigation funds shall not be used for general entertainment purposes. 
(2)  The rental and maintenance of real property required for covert confidential investigation operations. 
(3)  The hiring of interpreters, specialists and/or special police officers required for the execution of covert confidential investigation missions where hiring by normal means would jeopardize the success of the mission. 
(4)  If certain items of supply and equipment are necessary in connection with a specific investigation and cannot be obtained through regular supply channels in time to meet the requirements of the investigation, the purchase on an emergency basis from confidential investigation funds is authorized. 
(d)  A separate record account will be established by the Chief of Police of all supplies and equipment purchased with confidential investigation funds. 
(1)  Any property which is consumed, lost or destroyed out of necessity in connection with an investigation may be dropped from accountability upon approval by the Mayor. 
(2)  Property which is not consumed or destroyed but which passes from Police control out of necessity in connection with an investigation may be dropped from accountability, provided any of the following conditions apply: 
A.  The property is uneconomically recoverable. 
B.  Recovery would prejudice the successful completion of the investigation. 
C.  Recovery would disclose investigative technique or disclose the identity of informants or the investigator. 
(3)  When the property is dropped from accountability, the responsible investigators will provide the Chief of Police with a report that the property was consumed, destroyed or otherwise passed from City control, presenting the reasons therefor and the identifying investigation in connection with which the property was used. 
(4)  Unserviceable and/or excess or obsolete property shall be destroyed in the presence of at least three witnesses, one of which shall be of which shall be the Chief of Police. 
(e)  The creation of this Confidential Investigation Fund is subject to the approval of the Bureau of Inspection and Supervision of Public Offices of the State of Ohio, and the Clerk of this Council is hereby authorized and directed to certify a copy of this section and send the same to the Bureau and to request the approval of the Bureau to the establishment of this Fund. 
(f)  The Chief of Police is responsible to the Mayor for the administration of the Confidential Investigation Fund. 
(Ord. 71-64. Passed 5-3-71.) 
(g)  There is hereby transferred to the Confidential Investigation Fund account $1,000.00 from the Law Enforcement Trust Fund. 
(Ord. 04-49. Passed 4-5-04.)

125.24 - Community Development Block Grant Fund.

125.27 - Accrued Benefits Fund. 
(a)  There is hereby established an Accrued Benefits Fund which shall be used to pay the sick leave, vacation and longevity due an employee upon termination of service with the City. (Ord. 86-122. Passed 11-3-86.) 
(b)  For the year 2008 
    All Municipal Income Tax receipts shall be credited to the General Fund. 
    Effective 1/1/2009 
    All Municipal Income Tax receipts shall be apportioned with 94 per percent credited to the General Fund, four percent to Equipment Replacement Funds and two percent to the Accrued Benefits Fund. 
(Ord. 08-31. Passed 4-7-08.) 
(c)  The Accrued Benefits Fund balance shall be invested as provided in such Chapter 171 and such Fund credited with any interest income earned. 
(d)  The Director of Finance shall report to Council when it appears the Accrued Benefits Fund is fully vested, and Council may adjust the Municipal Income Tax apportionment as necessary within the two percent Income Tax credit limit. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the above, the Emergency Paramedic Fund and the Parks and Recreation Fund shall be excluded from this funding since they have specific property tax levies. 
(Ord. 86-122. Passed 11-3-86.) 
125.28 - Police Division Trust Funds. 
(a)  Law Enforcement Trust Fund. Council authorizes the creation of the Law Enforcement Trust Fund. The Director of Finance shall be responsible for keeping all financial records, including record of all deposits and expenditures of the funds: 
(1)  Proceeds from the seizure and/or sale of forfeited contraband obtained by the Police Division, and proceeds from mandatory fines and bail forfeitures paid by the Clerk of Courts as a result of a conviction or failure to appear for a drug offense pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 2925 shall be deposited into this Fund. 
(2)  Expenditures from the Fund shall be authorized solely by the Chief of Police and shall be utilized only for those purposes set forth in Ohio R.C. 2933.43(D) or as it may hereafter be amended. 
(b)  Alcohol Intervention/Education Trust Fund. Council authorizes the creation of the Alcohol Intervention/Education Trust Fund. The Director of Finance shall be responsible for keeping all financial records, including record of all deposits and expenditures of the funds: 
(1)  Proceeds from fines paid over to the Police Division by the Clerk of Courts pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4511.99 resulting from a conviction for drunk driving shall be deposited into this Fund. 
(2)  Expenditures from the Fund shall be authorized by the Chief of Police and shall be utilized only to fund the Police Division's efforts to enforce drunk driving laws, and to educate the public of laws governing operation of a motor vehicle while under the influence. 
(c)  Federal Equitable Sharing Fund. Council authorizes the creation of the Federal Equitable Sharing Fund for the purpose of the deposit of monies received from Federal Forfeitures and expenditures of monies only for law enforcement purposes in accordance with the statutes and guidelines that govern Equitable Sharing. 
(d)  By January 31 of each year the Chief of Police shall report to Council the deposits made for the preceding year into each of the above funds and the purposes for which the funds were expended. 
(Ord. 03-52. Passed 5-5-03.) 
125.29 - Sale of personal property. 
(a)  Personal property not needed for municipal purposes, the estimated value of which is less than, $5,000.00, may be sold by the Director having supervision or management thereof, or by their designee, in a manner determined by the Director having supervision or management thereof or by their designee, including but not limited to internet auction. If the estimated value of such property exceeds $5,000.00, it shall be sold as set forth in O.R.C. 721.15. 
(b)  Personal property not needed for municipal purposes, with minimal or no value as determined by the Director having supervision or management thereof, or by their designee, may be disposed of through refuse collection.
