Chapter 127 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Department established-see CHTR. Art. IV,  1. Duties of Director-see CHTR. Art. IV,  5. State law provisions-see Ohio R.C. 737.01 et seq. 

127.01 - Duties and powers of director. 
    The Director of Public Safety shall have the duties, obligations, powers and rights as set forth in the City Charter, and such further duties and obligations as may hereafter be prescribed by ordinance of Council. 
(Ord. 67-167. Passed 12-18-67.) 
127.02 - Compensation. 
    In the event that a person other than the Mayor is appointed and becomes qualified for the position of Director of Public Safety that person shall receive annual compensation as prescribed by the Council. 
(Ord. 67-167. Passed 12-18-67.) 
127.03 - Emergency alarms. 
(a)  Authority to install alarm. Any residence or lawful business located within the City may be equipped with an emergency alarm for the purpose of detecting and signaling the presence of a fire or unauthorized intrusion upon compliance with this section. Existing installations shall be subject to the requirements of this section, including those pertaining to permits. 
(b)  Local alarms. A permit for the installation of a local alarm which, when activated, sounds a horn, bell, buzzer or other type of audible alarm, shall be required if the sound created by the alarm is audible beyond the premises being served. The Director of Public Safety or his authorized representative shall issue a permit for such an alarm, provided the intensity of sound does not exceed 65 decibels at any location outside the premises being served. 
(c)  False alarms. 
(1)  Charges as follows shall be assessed for false alarms received in any 12-month period through equipment described above, or for each false alarm received through any other alarm service which the City has given permission to be installed. Such fee shall be assessed against the holder of the permit for the alarm with which the false alarm is associated. 
False Alarm Charges 1st-3rd No charge 4th-5th $25.00 each 6th through 8th $50.00 each 9th or more $100.00 each  
(2)  Notwithstanding the fee to be assessed, as set forth above, there shall be no charge for a false alarm to which there is no response by the Police or Fire Divisions, nor when the cause has been proven to be an act of God. 
(d)  General . 
(1)  All equipment used in installations for which a permit is required shall meet the applicable standards of the Underwriters Laboratories and/or the National Fire Protection Association and/or other recognized industry standard. The applicant may be required to submit evidence of the reliability and suitability of the equipment to be installed. 
(2)  The sensory mechanism used in connection with such devices must be adjusted to suppress false indications of fire or intrusion, so that the devices will not be actuated by impulses due to transient pressure change in water pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises such as the rattling or vibrating of doors or windows, vehicular noise adjacent to the installation, or other forces unrelated to genuine alarms. 
(3)  All components comprising such a device must be maintained by the owner or lessee in good repair to assure reliability of operation. 
(4)  Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases to a person an automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the City shall furnish that person with instructions as to the way the device operates, along with maintenance instructions. 
(5)  Each alarm equipment supplier shall also furnish the Police Chief and/or Fire Chief with a copy of the instructions as to the way the device operates. If the Police Chief and/or Fire Chief find such to be incomplete, unclear or otherwise inadequate, he may require the alarm equipment supplier to have the same revised to meet his approval and then promptly have copies distributed to persons for whom installations of such devices are made. 
(6)  Each alarm equipment supplier that sells or leases to a person an automatic protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the City for which a permit is required must provide for receiving calls for service, directly or through an agent, on a 24-hour basis, seven days a week, and shall respond to such calls within eight hours of the time they are received. Such supplier must notify the Police or Fire Division of any change of its address, phone number and/or personnel. 
(7)  At the time of installation, each alarm equipment supplier shall furnish to the person for whom an automatic protection device has been installed, written information as to how service can be obtained at any time, including the telephone number to call for service; and such person shall be responsible for having the device repaired as quickly as possible after he learns, either from his own sources or from notification by the City, that the device is not working properly. 
(8)  The Police Chief and Fire Chief or any officer designated by them shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon oral notice, to enter upon any premises within the City, to inspect the installation and operation of an automatic protection device or signaling device, the purpose of which is to report an emergency to the Police and/or Fire Station. 
(9)  All equipment, the use or installation of which is subject to this section, shall be maintained in good operating condition. The Police Chief and/or Fire Chief may require that repairs be made whenever he has determined that such are necessary to assure proper operation. 
(e)  Liability of city. The issuance of any permit or permits in conjunction with this section shall not constitute acceptance by the City of any liability to maintain any equipment, to answer alarms, or for anything in connection therewith. 
(f)  Rules and regulations. The Director of Public Safety or his authorized representative shall make and enforce such rules and regulations as he may deem necessary for the enforcement of the provisions hereof, and for the proper determination and collection of the fees and charges herein provided. 
(g)  Penalty . Whoever violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor, the penalty for which shall be prescribed by Section 501.99. 
(Ord. 98-75. Passed 9-21-98.) 
Chapter 128 - REPEALED 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 82-7, adopted Feb. 15, 1982, repealed Ch. 128, which pertained to private police. 
Chapter 129 - DIVISION OF POLICE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Director of Public Safety as head of Division of Police-see CHTR. Art. IV,  5. Pension and Disability Funds-see CHTR. Art. XIII,  2; Ohio R.C. Ch. 742. Auxiliary Police Unit-see ADM. Ch. 130. Police Record System Fund-see ADM. 125.12. Confidential Investigation Fund-see ADM. 125.14. 

129.01 - Division of Police established. 
(a)  There is created a Division of Police in the City which shall be divided into two sections, one section consisting of full-time members of the Division and one section consisting of part-time members of the Division. Part-time members shall be designated "deputy police officers." 
(b)  For the purposes of this chapter, wherever the word "patrolmen" is used it shall apply to both sexes, male and female, and hereafter shall be synonymous with "police officers." Wherever the word "patrolman" or "patrolmen" is used, "police officer" shall be substituted. 
(Ord. 76-142. Passed 10-18-76.) 
129.02 - Members. 
(a)  The Division of Police shall consist of: 
(1)  One Chief of Police; 
(2)  Not more than two Lieutenants of Police; 
(3)  Not more than four Sergeants of Police; 
(4)  Not more than 16 police officers; 
(5)  Not more than seven deputy police officers; 
(6)  Not more than two full-time and nine part-time dispatchers; 
(7)  The hiring of the twenty-third police officer shall be contingent upon Council's prior approval by motion of the funding thereof. 
(b)  The Chief of Police may appoint not more than three members from the ranks to act as Detectives of Police. 
(c)  Whenever an anticipated vacancy or vacancies occur in the ranks of Chief of Police, Lieutenants or Sergeants of Police or police officers, the authorized number of members designated in subsection (a) hereof shall be increased by the number of such anticipated vacancies for only so long as such vacancy or vacancies continue. It is the intent of this subsection to provide for a temporary increase in complement of the Division in order that a new member begin training in anticipation of a vacancy in the Division, at which time the complement shall revert back to the number provided for under subsection (a) hereof. 
(Ord. 15-54. Passed 6-29-15.) 
129.03 - Appointments. 
(a)  All members of the Division of Police, except those who have not completed service of their probationary period, shall reside within the City of Bay Village or within a 20-mile radius from the center of Bay Village. If the 20-mile radius enters any city or township, the entire city or township shall be included in the residency requirement. 
(Ord. 05-43. Passed 5-2-05.) 
(b)  No person shall be eligible to take an examination for and receive an original appointment as a member of the Division of Police unless he has reached the age of 21. 
(c)  Separate examinations shall be given and separate eligibility lists shall be maintained by the Civil Service Commission for original appointments to full-time positions and part-time positions. No person may be transferred from the part-time list to the full-time list, provided however, that any person who qualifies shall have his name placed on both the full-time and part-time eligibility lists. To be eligible to take an examination for a part-time position, an applicant must have had not less than one year's experience as a member of an organized police department and must possess a certificate from the Executive Director of the Ohio Peace Officer Training Council attesting to his satisfactory completion of the basic course as prescribed by Ohio R.C. 109.71 through 109.78 inclusive, and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. 83-41. Passed 3-21-83.) 
129.04 - Powers and duties. 
    Each member of the Division of Police shall generally have and exercise the police powers and authority and perform the police duties provided for in Ohio Revised Code 737.18 and 737.19, together with such other powers and duties not inconsistent with the nature of such offices as may be conferred or imposed by ordinance. 
(Ord. 5243. Passed 10-24-41.) 
129.05 - Hours of work. 
(a)  Full-time members of the Division of Police shall work not less than 40 hours in each calendar week, except that the Chief of Police shall have duty hours as assigned by the Director of Public Safety. 
(b)  Part-time members of the Division of Police shall work from time to time as directed by the Director of Public Safety. 
(Ord. 78-24. Passed 3-20-78.) 
129.06 - Emergency appointments. 
    The Mayor, the Director of Public Safety, Chief of Police or Acting Chief of Police in emergencies shall have the power to appoint and deputize such additional policemen as such emergencies may require, but such appointments shall extend only for the duration of the emergency. The Mayor shall also have the power to appoint as policeman any employee of the City not a regular member of the Division of Police, who in his opinion can better discharge his duties as such employee if clothed with police power. Such appointment shall be revocable at the will of the Mayor and no such policeman shall be required to give bond as such, nor shall he receive any compensation as such. 
(Ord. 5657. Passed 1-2-45.) 
129.07 - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the members of the Division of Police shall be as fixed from time to time by ordinance. 
(Ord. 5243. Passed 10-24-41.) 
129.08 - Repealed. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 59-137 repealed  129.08, which pertained to annual leave of absence for police. 
129.09 - Director of Public Safety authority for rules and regulations. 
    The Director of Public Safety is authorized to promulgate and enforce rules and regulations for the conduct of the Division of Police and control the conduct of the members of the Division. Willful violation of such rules and regulations shall constitute grounds for the removal of the offender. 
(Ord. 5243. Passed 10-24-41.) 
129.10 - Jailer. 
    The Chief of Police is authorized to employ a jailer, male or female, when in his discretion it is necessary in the premises. The duties of the jailer shall be those assigned by the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. 54-40. Passed 2-16-54.) 
129.11 - Police Relief and Pension Fund. 
    House Bill 642, enacted by the 1965 session of the 106th Ohio General Assembly, created a Statewide disability and pension fund for policemen and firemen and abolishes all municipal police relief and pension funds as of January 1, 1967. See Ohio R.C. Chapter 742. 
129.12 - Document copying fee; excess payments. 
(a)  The following charges for copies of records of the Police Division are hereby established: 
Photocopy of documents 1-10 pages No Charge Photocopy of documents 11 or more pages, (per page) retroactive to 1st page $ .10 Photographic print (not enlarged) $1.00 Photographic print (5 x 7 enlargement) $4.00 Photographic print (8 x 10 enlargement) $7.00 Flash drive $7.00 Optical digital disc $3.00  
(Ord. 02-119. Passed 9-16-02.) 
(b)  In the event a request is received for copies of documents which request is accompanied by an advance payment in excess of the rates established in this section, said excess, together with the required charge, shall be credited to the General Fund. Upon request, by the person paying for the document, a refund of the amount in excess of the charges set forth in (a) above shall be made by the City. 
(Ord. 75-30. Passed 3-17-75.) 
( Ord. No. 18-22,  1, 4-9-2018) 
129.13 - Repealed. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 80-35, adopted Apr. 21, 1980, repealed  129.13, which pertained to uniform allowance. 
129.14 - School guard unit. 
(a)  There is hereby created within the Division of Police of the Department of Public Safety a School Guard Unit. The maximum number of school guards who may be appointed pursuant to this section is not more than eight. 
(b)  Upon recommendation of the Chief of Police, such school guard shall be appointed by the Director of Public Safety and shall not be under the classified service of the City. School guards shall not be entitled to any benefits other than those provided under the compensation ordinances of the City. School guards shall protect the children of the City while on their way to and from the schools located in the City. 
(c)  The stations of duty of the respective school guards shall be assigned by the Chief of Police and, in the absence of the Chief, by the Director. 
(d)  The hours of duty, rules and regulations, duties and powers of the school guards shall be promulgated by the Chief of Police. 
(e)  The Director is authorized to prescribe by rules and regulations the type of uniform or part thereof which shall be worn by members of the School Guard Unit. 
(Ord. 98-104. Passed 12-7-98.) 
129.15 - Fee for use of city jail. 
    There is hereby established a rate of $55.00 per day plus medical expenses incurred during incarceration for a sentenced prisoner or any prisoner housed for the Cuyahoga County Sheriff's Department, and $100.00 per day plus medical expenses incurred during incarceration for all other types of prisoners for the use of the City Jail facilities in the housing of prisoners by other governmental entities. 
(Ord. 10-21. Passed 3-1-10.) 
129.16 - Bay Family Services Advisory Board. 
(a)  There is hereby created within the Division of Police, a Bay Family Services Advisory Board. The purpose of the Advisory Board will be to promote a cooperative partnership between the schools, law enforcement, juvenile court, families and the community in dealing with the problems of children and families. Through education, intervention, and diversion, the Advisory Board shall help to restore and support the authority of the parents and empower youth and parents to make positive and proactive changes. Youth under the age of 18 may be referred for assistance by the Police Division, the Youth Commission or the Bay Village City Schools. 
(b)  The Bay Family Services Advisory Board will advise the Chief of Police on the appointment of necessary professional staff, establish and review policy and procedures, budgeting and funding. The Advisory Board shall meet as needed to review case loads, evaluate program progress and make recommendations to the Chief of Police. The Advisory Board shall file a written annual report with the Mayor, Bay Village School Superintendent, City Council and Bay Village School Board no later than February 1 of each and every year. 
(c)  The Bay Family Services Advisory Board shall be comprised of city, school, juvenile court, community members and a member of City Council. A Chairperson for the Board shall be chosen by the Board and will serve as a liaison to the Chief of Police. All associated costs will be shared equally between the City of Bay Village and Bay Board of Education. 
(d)  Council shall review the effectiveness of the Bay Family Services Advisory Board after the first initial year to determine if this Board is a viable contributing body to the City. 
(Ord. 97-68. Passed 6-30-97.) 
Chapter 130 - AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Safety Director to head Division of Police-see CHTR. Art. IV,  5. Auxiliary police unit-see Ohio R.C. 737.051, 737.06. Division of Police-see ADM. Ch. 129. 

130.01 - Creation; appointment of members. 
    There is hereby created within the Division of Police an Auxiliary Police Unit to consist of not more than 35 persons, who shall be appointed by the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
130.02 - Term of service. 
    Auxiliary Police officers shall serve so long as the Chief of Police may direct, or until a resignation submitted by such member shall be accepted by the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
130.03 - Qualifications of members. 
    The members of the Auxiliary Police Unit may not be under the age of 21 years at the time of their appointment, and shall meet such other requirements as provided by the rules and regulations in Section 130.05. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
130.04 - Chief of Police to control unit. 
    The Chief of Police shall be the executive officer of the Auxiliary Police Unit and shall have control of the assignment, training and stationing of the members and the direction of work. 
    The Auxiliary Police Unit shall perform only such police duties as assigned by the Chief of Police, and shall act only when in the prescribed uniform or portion of uniform. The Chief of Police shall prescribe the time and place such uniform or portion thereof shall be worn. Such Auxiliary members shall obey the chain of command of the Division of Police and shall take orders from all regular appointed members thereof. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
130.05 - Rules and regulations. 
    The Chief of Police shall prescribe the rules and regulations for the organization, administration, conduct and control of the Auxiliary Police Unit. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
130.06 - Uniform. 
    The Chief of Police is authorized to prescribe by rules and regulations the type of uniform or part thereof which shall be worn by members of the Auxiliary Police Unit. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
130.07 - Service on voluntary basis; compensation. 
(a)  All services performed by Auxiliary officers shall be on a voluntary basis. 
(b)  Auxiliary officers shall not be entitled to any benefits of any relief or pension funds of the City of the State, or any other similar benefits. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
130.08 - Nonliability. 
    This chapter is declared by Council as an exercise by the City of its police powers for the protection of the public peace, health, property, safety and general welfare. The City, or agent or representative of the City, an officer appointed under the provisions of this chapter, or any individual, firm, partnership or corporation, or the receiver, trustee or any agent thereof, who in good faith executes any executive order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, shall not be liable for injury or damage sustained to person or property as the direct proximate result of such action. In addition to any other responsibilities or immunities, the members of the Auxiliary Police Unit shall bear the same responsibilities and the same immunities as any other regularly employed member of the Division of Police of the City, except as herein provided. 
(Ord. 09-15. Passed 3-16-09.) 
Chapter 131 - DIVISION OF FIRE[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference- Director of Public Safety to be head of the Division of Fire-see CHTR. Art. IV,  5. Pension and Disability Funds-see CHTR. Art. XIII,  2; Ohio R.C. Ch. 742. State law provisions-see Ohio R.C. 737.08 et seq. Fires and fire prevention-see GEN. OFF. Ch. 515. Misconduct at an emergency-see GEN. OFF. 509.05. False alarms-see GEN. OFF. 509.07. Fires in parks-see GEN. OFF. 539.07(d). Fire prevention-see FIRE PREVENTION CODE, Part Seventeen. 

131.01 - Division established. 
(a)  There is established a Division of Fire for the City, consisting of a Fire Chief, three captains, four lieutenants, and at least 18 but not to exceed 20 firefighters. The Chief of the Division shall assign one lieutenant as the Fire Safety Inspector. 
(Ord. 09-21. Passed 4-6-09.) 
(b)  For the purpose of this chapter, whenever the word "fireman" is used it shall apply to both sexes, male and female, and hereafter shall be synonymous with "firefighter." Whenever the word "fireman" or "firemen" is used, "firefighter" shall be substituted. 
(Ord. 78-25. Passed 3-20-78.) 
(c)  Whenever an anticipated vacancy or vacancies occur in the ranks of Fire Chief, Captains or Lieutenants of Fire or firefighters, the authorized number of members designated in subsection (a) hereof shall be increased by the number of such anticipated vacancies for only so long as such vacancy or vacancies continue. It is the intent of this subsection to provide for a temporary increase in complement of the Division in order that a new member begin training in anticipation of a vacancy in the Division, at which time the complement shall revert back to the number provided for under subsection (a) hereof. 
(Ord. 88-55. Passed 5-2-88.) 
131.02 - Appointments. 
    All officers and firemen in the Division of Fire shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall be under the laws, ordinances and rules of the Civil Service Commission of the City. 
(Ord. 70-187. Passed 1-11-71.) 
131.03 - Policemen as deputies. 
    The policemen provided for in Chapter 129 shall be eligible to appointment to any deputy position in the Division of Fire, but if so appointed shall receive no additional compensation excepting for services rendered while not on duty in their capacity as policemen. 
(Ord. 70-187. Passed 1-11-71.) 
131.04 - Duties and authority. 
    The Division of Fire shall be charged with the prevention of fires, the protection of life and property against fire, the operation of the City ambulance and Emergency Paramedic Unit, and shall: 
(a)  Be responsible for the maintenance and care of all property and equipment used by the Division and in accordance with the directions of the Director of Public Safety and in the maintenance of all City-owned equipment. 
(b)  Make a record of all fire, ambulance and Emergency Paramedic Unit calls. 
(c)  Perform various miscellaneous public services of an emergency nature. 
(d)  Inspect potential fire hazards and abate existing fire hazards. 
(e)  Conduct an educational fire prevention program. 
(f)  Inspect fire hydrants. 
(g)  Perform such other duties as are directed by the Director of Public Safety which are not inconsistent with the duties of the Division of Fire. 
(h)  Perform such other duties as are provided by ordinance. 
    The Fire Chief shall be in full charge of the equipment and personnel of the Division of Fire. 
(Ord. 78-70. Passed 5-15-78.) 
131.05 - Hours. 
    Each member of the Division of Fire, other than the Chief, deputies and those assigned as Fire Safety Inspectors shall be on duty 300 hours in each six-week period (but further shall not exceed 240 hours in a 28-day period) in such shifts as may be arranged by the Chief so that each firefighter is on duty for a shift of not more than 24 hours in each 48-hour period, except in cases of emergency or in line of duty at the time of a fire. 
    The person assigned as Fire Safety Inspector shall be on duty 40 hours each week. The Fire Chief shall have duty hours as assigned by the Director of Public Safety. 
(Ord. 80-24. Passed 3-17-80.) 
131.06 - Deputy firemen on duty. 
    Each deputy fireman, in addition to his duties when actually called to a fire or other emergency, shall be on duty, when assigned by the Chief, at the Fire Station continuously from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m., as an assistant to the firemen on duty at that time. 
(Ord. 70-187. Passed 1-11-71.) 
131.07 - Employment of temporary deputies. 
    In emergencies the Fire Chief, or in his absence, the officer in charge, is authorized to employ deputies temporarily to assist the Division in its work of actual fire extinguishment and control. 
(Ord. 70-187. Passed 1-11-71.) 
131.08 - Public safety watches reclassified as firemen. 
    All persons now classified as Public Safety Watches shall hereafter be classified as firemen, and such transfer of title shall not affect said employee's civil service status or rights. 
(Ord. 51-21. Passed 2-6-51.) 
131.09 - Firemens relief and pension fund established. 
    House Bill 642, enacted by the 1965 session of the 106th Ohio General Assembly, created a Statewide disability and pension fund for policemen and firemen and abolishes all municipal firemen's relief and pension funds as of January 1, 1967. See Ohio R.C. Chapter 742. 
131.10 - Residence. 
    All members of the Division of Fire, except those who have not completed service of their probationary period, shall reside in the City of Bay Village or within a 15-mile radius from the City Hall of Bay Village. Such residency requirements are mandatory and failure of any member of the Division to so reside as herein specified shall require his immediate dismissal from such Division. 
(Ord. 87-113. Passed 9-8-87.) 
131.11 - Prior approval for emergency response to other subdivisions. 
    The use, in any other subdivision of the State of Ohio in times of emergency, of the fire apparatus and the services of the members of the Division of Fire, is hereby authorized pursuant to the provisions of Ohio R.C. 717.021, when first approved by the Mayor or the Director of Public Safety. 
(Ord. 67-11. Passed 3-6-67.) 
131.12 - Repealed. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 80-35, adopted Apr. 21, 1980, repealed  131.12, which pertained to uniform allowance. 
131.13 - Personal nonliability performing paramedic duties. 
    Any claim or suit brought against any member or employee of the Division of Fire or the Division of Police of the City, arising from or because of any action or inaction by such member or employee in the scope of his employment as a member or assistant to such member of a medical emergency unit or paramedic unit or other emergency unit on a medical assignment operated by the Division of Fire shall be defended by the City until the final termination of the proceedings therein. The City shall save such member or employee of the Division of Fire or the Division of Police harmless from personal liability or any judgment resulting from such claim or suit defended by the City. 
(Ord. 76-10. Passed 2-17-76.)

    There is created the post of Director of Civil Defense.

133.02 - Appointment; compensation. 
    The Director of Civil Defense shall be appointed by the Mayor and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. The Director of Civil Defense shall not receive compensation for his services in that position. 
(Ord. 57-165. Passed 11-18-57.) 
133.03 - Duties. 
    The Director of Civil Defense shall have the responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of a program of civil defense within the City and may in collaboration with public and private agencies within the State or the Federal government develop mutual aid arrangements, provided, however, all agreements reached with any such agencies or the Federal government must be authorized by legislative action of Council. 
(Ord. 57-165. Passed 11-18-57.) 
133.04 - Repealed.

Chapter 140 - DEPARTMENT OF COMMUNITY SERVICES[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Cross reference- Meals at cost to elderly-see Ohio R.C. 3313.81. Medical assistance program-see Ohio R.C. 5101.53. Federal supplements to aid-see Ohio R.C. 5101.53. 

140.01 - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established a Department of Community Services for the City. 
(Ord. 12-09. Passed 2-27-12.) 
140.02 - Powers and duties of department. 
    The Department of Community Services shall provide a central resource wherein individuals of all ages can obtain assistance or information concerning the solving of their social service problems. The Department shall: 
(a)  Develop, cultivate and bring together the Community Services of the community in assisting senior citizens, residents with disabilities and others with their problems; 
(b)  Encourage and work with public and private agencies in establishing facilities and programs within the City that deal with needs such as social services, employment, nutrition, transportation, health, low income and youth and family services; 
(c)  Direct or bring together groups or individuals willing to donate their time or services in helping others and encourage voluntary funds for such purposes; and 
(d)  Develop and/or coordinate social, educational, recreational and wellness programs and service opportunities for senior citizens which will improve their quality of life. 
(Ord. 12-09. Passed 2-27-12.) 
140.03 - Director. 
    The Department of Community Services shall be headed by a Director who shall be appointed by the Mayor with the concurrence of a majority of the members of Council provided for in the Charter, and who shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. 
    Within the Department of Community Services there is established the position of Assistant Director of Community Services, appointed by the Mayor, who shall perform such duties as are delegated by the Director. 
(Ord. 12-09. Passed 2-27-12.) 
140.04 - Community Services Advisory Board. 
(a)  Creation . There is hereby created an advisory board to be known as the Community Services Advisory Board which shall consist of eight members appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by a majority of the members of Council provided for in the Charter, and a representative appointed by Council. Each member shall serve for a term of three years, except that in the event a high school student is appointed and qualified as one of the eight members, he or she shall serve for a term of two years. Any vacancy shall be filled in the same manner as an original appointment for the unexpired term. 
(b)  Powers and duties. The Community Services Advisory Board shall meet quarterly, or more frequently as deemed necessary, for the purpose of advising and assisting the Director in the establishment of policies and procedure with respect to prospective programs or activities deemed necessary to carry out the purpose of the Department as outlined in this chapter. The Board shall also confer with the Mayor and Council relative to the establishment of programs designed to meet the human needs of the residents of the City. 
(c)  Rules and regulations. The Board shall adopt rules and regulations with respect to the conducting of meetings which shall be consistent with the purpose and intent of the powers and duties set out in this section. A president of the Board shall be elected by a majority of the members of the Board at the first meeting of each calendar. 
(Ord. 12-09. Passed 2-27-12.) 
140.05 - Dwyer Memorial Fund. 
(a)  Creation . There is hereby created an emergency fund to be known as the Dwyer Memorial Fund. Such Fund is to receive moneys and/or property donated to the City for such Fund. 
(b)  Purpose . The Fund shall be used for emergency situations where there is a critical need for medical care, food, shelter, protection, safety and/or counseling for the citizens and residents of the City. 
(c)  Disbursements . When the Director of Community Services determines there is an emergency situation, she may expend up to $250.00 when it is determined a person has no personal resources to cover the emergency, when the person's family is unable or unwilling to help, when no other agency is able to help, or when temporary help is needed until another agency can help. Any expenditure exceeding the sum of $250.00 shall be approved by the Community Services Advisory Board prior to expenditure. No expenditure shall be made in excess of the balance in such Fund. 
(d)  Guidelines . The Director of Community Services and the Community Services Advisory Board shall establish guidelines and procedure for the use of the Fund. 
(Ord. 12-09. Passed 2-27-12.) 
Chapter 141 - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SERVICE AND PROPERTIES[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference- Department established-see CHTR. Art. IV,  1. Powers of Director-see CHTR. Art. IV,  6. Department of Public Service-see Ohio R.C. 735.02. Supervising sidewalk construction-see S. & P.S. 903.01. License for utility lights, poles or lines on public property-see S. & P.S. 917.01. 

141.01 - Minimum time. 
    Whenever a full-time employee is called in for work or services, other than for regularly scheduled hours, he/she shall receive a minimum compensation of two hours as "minimum time" at the rate established for his/her position in the then current compensation ordinance. 
(Ord. 85-6. Passed 3-4-85.) 
Chapter 142 - DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Cross reference- Department established-see CHTR.  8.1. Park Regulations-see General Offenses, Chapter 539. 

142.01 - Director of recreation. 
    The head of the Department of Parks and Recreation shall be designated the Director of Recreation, who shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the Mayor, except that no appointment shall be effective without the concurrence of a majority of the total number of Councilmen provided for in the Charter. 
(Ord. 94-126. Passed 12-29-94.) 
142.02 - Duties and powers of director. 
    The Director of Recreation shall be responsible for development and implementation of recreation programs. The Director shall administer the recreation program of the City with assistance of the Parks and Recreation Commission as hereinafter constituted. 
(Ord. 94-126. Passed 12-29-94.) 
142.03 - Parks and Recreation Commission. 
    There is established a Parks and Recreation Commission which shall consist of eight members. One shall be a member of City Council. One (who, if not a School Board Member shall be confirmed by Council as hereinafter provided) shall be appointed by the Board of Education for a term of one year. Six members shall be electors of the City appointed by the Mayor for four-year terms. Appointments of the Mayor and, if required, of the representative of the School Board, shall not be effective without the concurrence of a majority of the total number of Councilmen provided for in the Charter. Members appointed by the Mayor shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor. A vacancy occurring during the term of any member shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner authorized for the original appointment. 
(Ord. 74-123. Passed 9-3-74.) 
142.04 - Commission chairman. 
    During the regular meeting held in January of each calendar year, the Commission shall elect a chairman of the Parks and Recreation Commission. 
(Ord. 74-76. Passed 6-24-74.) 
142.05 - Organization and meetings of the commission. 
    The Chairman shall preside at all meetings. The Secretary of the Director of Recreation shall serve as secretary for the Commission. The Commission shall hold meetings as may be called by the Chairman or upon the request of the Director of Recreation, Council representative, or at least two members of the Commission. 
(Ord. 00-116. Passed 12-4-00.) 
142.06 - Powers and duties of the commission. 
    The Commission shall: 
(a)  Provide for its own organization; 
(b)  Advise the Director of Recreation with respect to the planning and organization, within the limitations of available funds, a year round recreation program for the residents of the City of all ages, which promotes the health, welfare, and physical and mental well-being of the residents, and provides an opportunity for wholesome utilization of their leisure time; 
(c)  Recommend to the Director of Recreation all fees and charges for participation in recreational activities, including the City Swimming Pool, and shall approve the proposed budget for said recreational program submitted by the Director of Recreation prior to its being approved or modified by Mayor and Council; 
(d)  Act as advisors to the Council, the Planning Commission and the Cahoon Park Trustees in connection with the short and long range planning and implementation of the acquisition, development and improvement of existing physical park and recreational facilities and properties including Cahoon Memorial Park. 
(Ord. 94-126. Passed 12-29-94.) 
142.07 - Funds. 
    Council shall appropriate for Parks and Recreation such funds as it deems necessary and sufficient for the development and implementation of recreational programs. 
(Ord. 94-126. Passed 12-29-94.) 
142.08 - Designation of parks and recreation facilities. 
    For the purpose of interpretation and application of this Chapter, the following lands and facilities are hereby designated as "parks and recreation facilities and properties": 
(a)  PP 204-26-68 and 69, plus the parcel of land deeded to City of Bay Village as recorded in Cuyahoga County Recorder's records, Vol. 9090, Page 734, dated 6-18-58, located on the east side of Clague Road; 
(b)  PP 201-24-2, 201-22-01 and 201-22-02 located on the west side of Bradley Road; 
(c)  PP 204-4-41, City-owned parcel located between Lake Road and Lake Erie at the intersection of Lake Road and Columbia Road; 
(d)  PP 203-2-1, PP 203-1-2 and 3 (Cahoon Park) being that land bounded by Wolf Road, Dover Road, Lake Erie and Huntington Park Reservation, including all buildings and residences, excepting all roads and drives and the Service Center and its related structures; 
(e)  PP 202-4-2, Cemetery at 29040 Lake Road; 
(f)  PP 203-25-49 and 203-25-26 located at Elmwood Road near Norfolk and Western Railway; and 
(g)  PP 203-28-Block "A" located between Glen Park Drive and West Glen Park Drive north of Wolf Road. 
(Ord. 75-113. Passed 9-2-75.) 
142.09 - Designation of historical area. 
    The following parks and recreation facilities and properties are hereby designated as an historical area to be preserved and restored, which are part of the lands and facilities listed under C.O. Section 142.08; the area bounded by Cahoon Road on the west, Lake Road on the north from Cahoon Road to the west bank of Cahoon Creek, Lake Erie on the north, the east bank of Cahoon Creek on the east, and Wolf Road on the South. More specifically, said area is described as follows: 
Beginning at the intersection of the centerlines of Wolf Road and Cahoon Road which point is the proper place of beginning; 
Thence Northerly along the centerline of Cahoon Road a distance of 1,020.90 feet to a point; 
Thence Northerly along the centerline of Cahoon Road on an arc whose cord is 398.21 feet to a point; 
Thence continuing along the centerline of Cahoon Road 226.28 feet to the centerline of Lake Road (80 feet); 
Thence Easterly along the centerline of Lake Road 511.9 feet to a point; 
Thence Northerly approximately 220 feet along the West bank of Cahoon Creek at an outside angle of approximately 125 degrees to Lake Road to a point; 
Thence Northerly at an outside angle of about 147 degrees a distance of approximately 170 feet to the waters edge of Lake Erie; 
Thence Easterly at an inside angle of about 61 degrees along the waters edge approximately 220 feet to a point; 
Thence Southerly at an inside angle of about 115 degrees approximately 370 feet to a point in the centerline of Lake Road, which point is approximately 1,180 feet Westerly from the centerline of Dover Center Road; 
Thence Southerly at an inside angle of about 170 degrees a distance of approximately 210 feet to a point; 
Thence Southerly at an outside angle of about 145 degrees approximately 410 feet to a point; 
Thence Southerly at an inside angle of about 159 degrees approximately 345 feet to a point; 
Thence Southerly at an outside angle of 137 degrees approximately 460 feet to a point; 
Thence Southerly at an inside angle of about 139 degrees a distance of approximately 105 feet to the centerline of Wolf Road; 
Thence Westerly at an angle of about 90 degrees to Wolf Road a distance of approximately 415 feet to the place of beginning. 
(Ord. 75-114. Passed 9-2-75.) 
142.10 - Minimum time. 
    Whenever a full-time employee is called in for work or services, other than for regularly scheduled hours, he/she shall receive a minimum compensation of two hours as "minimum time" at the rate established for his/her position in the then current compensation ordinance. 
(Ord. 85-5. Passed 3-4-85.) 
142.11 - Bay Community Band as department function. 
(a)  The City hereby establishes the Bay Community Band as a function of the Parks and Recreation Department of the City. 
(b)  Any and all donations or contributions to the Bay Community Band shall be forwarded to the Parks and Recreation Department. 
(Ord. 90-28. Passed 3-19-90.) 
Chapter 143 - PLANNING COMMISSION 
Editor's note- There are no sections in Chapter 143. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references and any future legislation.

Chapter 144 - COMMUNITY DIVERSION COMMISSION[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
Cross reference- Juvenile Court-see Ohio R.C. Ch. 2151. Minors curfew-see GEN. OFF. Ch. 531. 

144.01 - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established a Community Diversion Program, in accordance with the rules and regulations established by the Cuyahoga County Juvenile Court in the creation and governance of the Cuyahoga County Juvenile Court Community Diversion Program. The Mayor shall recommend for appointment by the Cuyahoga County Juvenile Court at least one Magistrate to serve on the Bay Village Community Diversion Program. The court appointed Magistrate shall be an attorney in good standing with the Supreme Court of the State of Ohio and shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and the Cuyahoga Juvenile Court. 
(Ord. 06-02. Passed 1-23-06.) 
144.02 - Powers and duties. 
    The Community Diversion Program shall meet as necessary for the purpose of hearing cases referred to it by Cuyahoga County Juvenile Court. The Magistrate shall conduct such hearings in a manner consistent with the Rules and Regulations of the Cuyahoga County Juvenile Court Community Diversion Program. 
(Ord. 06-02. Passed 1-23-06.) 
144.03 - Records. 
    All records generated by the Community Diversion Program and its commission shall be kept by the Bay Village Police Department in accordance with applicable law and juvenile court rules. 
(Ord. 06-02. Passed 1-23-06.) 
Chapter 145 - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION 
Editor's note- There are no sections in Chapter 145. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references and any future legislation.

Chapter 146 - TREE COMMISSION[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Cross reference- Trees-see GEN. OFF. Ch. 547. 

146.01 - Establishment. 
(a)  There is hereby established a Tree Commission which shall consist of seven members, who are either citizens of Bay Village or who may be employed in the City of Bay Village, five appointed by the Mayor with confirmation by a majority of the members of Council provided for in the Charter, a member of Council appointed by Council, and the Director of Public Service and Properties or his designee. The purpose of the Tree Commission is to assist City officials and City Council with the preservation, protection, and enhancement of the urban forest in the City of Bay Village. Two members shall be experienced in landscaping or have extensive knowledge of shade trees. The term of the five appointed members shall be for three years, expiring January 1. Any vacancy shall be filled in the same manner as an original appointment for the unexpired term. 
(b)  In order to stagger expiration dates, the initial Board members' terms shall terminate as follows: 
(1)  One member shall serve for a term of one year, two members shall serve for a term of two years, and two members shall serve for a term of three years, expiring January 1 of each year. 
(2)  The Council representative's term shall terminate upon expiration of their term in office. 
(3)  The City will appoint a secretary who shall serve at the pleasure of the Commission. 
(Ord. 98-103. Passed 11-2-98.) 
146.02 - Powers and duties. 
    The Tree Commission shall: 
(a)  Meet regularly once monthly, or a meeting may be called or canceled by the Chairperson or two members. A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. A majority of a quorum shall decide any matter before the Tree Commission. Prior to January 31 of each year, the Tree Commission shall meet and elect a member to serve as Chairperson. 
(b)  Study, investigate, plan, devise and recommend to Council and/or the Director of Public Service and Properties or his designee, any action, program, plan or legislation which the Tree Commission shall determine to be necessary or advisable for the care, preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees or shrubs in public ways, streets, alleys, parks, or other property owned by the City of Bay Village. 
(c)  Regulate the planting, maintenance and removal of trees and shrubs on City property and rights-of-way, to ensure safety and promote aesthetics. 
(d)  Appoint its own officers and committees, to make its own procedural rules, and to keep an accurate record of its proceedings and to make appropriate recommendations to the Mayor for nominees to the Tree Commission. 
(e)  Recommend to City Council the designation of any tree as "Grand and Glorious Tree." 
(f)  Interpret the language of this chapter and any other related ordinances, and determine its applicability to particular situations. 
(g)  Consider, investigate, make findings, and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its authority, upon request by the Mayor or Council. 
(h)  Act as an advisory or appeal board for the residents of the City who question or disagree with the City in matters pertaining to tree removal, planting and any other tree matters. 
(i)  Perform other responsibilities as may be from time to time prescribed by Council action. 
(Ord. 98-103. Passed 11-2-98.) 
146.03 - Reports. 
    The Tree Commission shall file written recommendations to the Mayor and Council prior to application for available grants for specific City projects setting forth such details as Council and the Mayor may require. The Tree Commission shall file a written annual report with the Mayor and Council no later than January 30 of each year, setting forth such details as Council and the Mayor may require of its activities for the previous year. 
(Ord. 98-103. Passed 11-2-98.)

Chapter 148 - RECORDS COMMISSION[21] 

Footnotes: 
--- (21) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-77 ,  1, adopted Nov. 23, 2015, amended Ch. 148 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 148,  148.01-148.04, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 77-119, passed 11-7-1977. 
Cross reference- Privacy Act Rules-see ADM. 151.12. State law provisions-see Ohio R.C. 149.39 et seq. 

148.01 - Establishment of commission. 
    There is hereby created and established in the City a Records Commission composed of the Mayor or their designee as chairman, and the Director of Finance, the Director of Law, and a citizen named by the Mayor. The Commission shall appoint a secretary who may or may not be a member of the Commission and who shall serve at the pleasure of the Commission. The Commission may employ an archivist to serve under its direction. The Commission shall meet at least once every six months and upon the call of the Chairperson. 
( Ord. No. 15-77 ,  1, 11-23-2015) 
148.02 - Functions of the commission. 
    The functions of the commission shall be to provide rules for retention and disposal of records of the municipal corporation, and to review applications for one-time disposal of obsolete records and to review schedules of records retention and disposition submitted by municipal offices. The commission may dispose of records pursuant to the procedure outlined in section 149.381 of the Revised Code. The commission, at any time, may review any schedule it has previously approved and, for good cause shown, may revise that schedule under the procedure outlined in that section. 
( Ord. No. 15-77 ,  1, 11-23-2015) 
148.03 - Disposal of records. 
    Records shall be disposed of per the regulations provided in ORC 149.381. 
( Ord. No. 15-77 ,  1, 11-23-2015) 
148.04 - Records and archives defined. 
    Any document, device or item, regardless of physical form or characteristic, created or received by or coming under the jurisdiction of any public office of the City which serves to document the organization, functions, policies, decisions, procedure, operations or other activities of the office, is a record within the meaning of this chapter. 
    Any public record which is transferred to an archival institution pursuant to this chapter because of the historical information contained therein shall be deemed to be an archive within the meaning of this chapter. 
( Ord. No. 15-77 ,  1, 11-23-2015) 
Chapter 149 - CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION[22] 

Footnotes: 
--- (22) --- 
Cross reference- Civil Service-see Ohio Const., Art. XV, Sec. 10; Ohio R.C. Ch. 124. Charter provisions-see CHTR. Art. VI. 

149.01 - Jurisdiction. 
    Effective at 12:01 am. on August 1, 1990, and continuing thereafter until otherwise ordered by this Council, the Civil Service Commission is hereby instructed not to provide services to the Bay Village Board of Education, Bay Village School System and/or their employees. 
(Ord. 90-75. Passed 7-9-90.) 
Chapter 150 - COMPENSATION PROCEDURAL GUIDELINES[23] 

Footnotes: 
--- (23) --- 
Cross reference- Employment provisions-see ADM. Ch. 151. Compensation payment dates-see ADM. 151.15. 

150.01 - Purpose and scope. 
    For the purpose of establishing and maintaining harmonious employment relationships and of achieving the best interests of the City, its employees, its residents and taxpayers, all in accordance with the orderly procedures as provided in this chapter, it is hereby declared to be the policy of Council to listen to and receive in writing presentations of the positions of the employees of the City with respect to their compensation and working conditions of employment, and to discuss such presentations and the City's positions thereon with representative(s) of such employees. The employee representative(s) shall listen to and receive in writing presentations of positions of the City with respect to compensation paid and working conditions of employment. For such purpose, the Council representative(s) shall meet, as provided in this chapter, with such members of each department's representative(s) duly elected or selected for such purpose by members of the departments, hereinafter in this chapter called Employee Representative(s). 
(Ord. 86-121. Passed 10-6-86.) 
150.02 - Procedure. 
(a)  By September 1 of the year in which the current agreement expires, Employee Representative(s) shall submit to Council, through the Mayor, a written list of requests with respect to compensation and working conditions of employment for members of their respective departments or divisions. The Mayor shall make his written recommendations thereon to Council by September 15 of such year. Upon or prior to Council's receipt of such recommendations of the Mayor, the President of Council shall appoint its representative(s), hereinafter in this chapter called Council Representative(s), for the informal discussions and presentations of positions provided for by this chapter. 
(b)  The Council Representative(s) shall respond, in writing, to such list of requests through the Mayor, to the Employee Representative(s) no later than October 1 of such year. Thereafter, in the event that differences then exist between the list of requests, the Mayor's recommendation thereon and/or the Council Representative(s)' response thereto, discussion shall be had and shall continue between both the Employee Representative(s) and the Council Representative(s), at mutually agreed upon times and places, with all parties endeavoring to discuss in good faith their respective positions in order to reach an agreement. The Mayor and/or his designated representative shall be notified of and may attend all such discussions. 
(c)  The Council Representative(s), the Mayor and the Employee Representative(s) may present, at any time during the course of such informal discussions and presentations of positions, any reasonable evidence, documentary or oral, going to the subject matter or matters under discussion. 
(d)  The Council Representative(s) shall keep the entire Council timely advised of actions and activities undertaken pursuant to this chapter, including, without intended limitation, timely presentation to the entire Council of the list of requests, the Mayor's recommendation thereon, the Council Representative(s)' response thereto and the Council Representative(s) recommendations from time to time to Council on the compensation and working conditions of employment under its consideration. 
(Ord. 86-121. Passed 10-6-86.) 
Chapter 151 - EMPLOYMENT PROVISIONS[24] 

Footnotes: 
--- (24) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, adopted June 20, 2016, amended Ch. 151 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 151,  151.01-151.20, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 14-08, passed 3-3-2014. Compensation and bond requirements are not included in these Codified Ordinances due to the fact that they are subject to constant change. 

151.01 - Payment to employees on military leave. 
(a)  All regular full-time employees of the City who are on leaves of absence from their Municipal duties and in attendance in the military service, field training or other active duty of the Ohio National Guard, Ohio Defense Corps, Ohio Naval Militia, or as members of other Reserve components of the Armed Forces of the United States, shall be entitled to receive for the period of such service, training or active duty not in excess of 31 days in any one calendar year, their regular pay, less the pay received for participation in such service, training or other active duty. Reimbursed expenses, travel and subsistence pay and other similar allowances shall not be considered in determining the amount of pay received for such service, training or active duty. Provisions of this section shall not apply if such military service, field training or other active duty is less than 72 consecutive hours or longer than 31 consecutive days. 
(b)  Any such City employee may, at his election, credit all or any portion of such military leave of absence against his regular annual vacation and for such period so charged the employee shall receive his regular vacation pay without deduction for the pay received for such service, training or active duty. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.02 - Payment of city wages during jury duty. 
(a)  All City employees shall receive their regular wages for time lost from their work with the City while serving as a member of a municipal, common pleas or federal court jury panel. 
(b)  In order to qualify for such pay, the employee shall notify his supervisor of such service in advance and upon completion of such service present proof satisfactory to the Director of Finance from the court as to the time spent in such service. 
(c)  No time spent in such service shall be counted or used for purposes of determining eligibility for overtime pay or compensatory time off. 
(d)  The employee may keep any amount received from the court for such services, in lieu of reimbursement for any expenses associated with such service. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.03 - Mileage allowance. 
    All employees and elected officials of the City shall receive, as reimbursement for the use of their personal motor vehicles on City business, a sum in accordance with the mileage allowance under the Internal Revenue Service Regulations, plus parking fees. The Director of Finance shall approve such reimbursement. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.031 - Legitimate expenses. 
    Tips and gratuities which are included in any legitimate expense shall be paid by the City. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.04 - Holidays. 
(a)  (1)  All full-time employees of the City, excluding employees covered under separate labor contract, shall have the following days off with pay: 
New Year's Day Day After Thanksgiving Presidents' Day Veterans' Day Good Friday Thanksgiving Day Memorial Day Christmas Day July 4th Martin Luther King Day Labor Day  
(2)  In the event that any of the aforesaid holidays shall fall on a Saturday or Sunday, when such holiday is not being observed on the preceding Friday or succeeding Monday, such employee shall receive comparable time off with pay on a date designated by the Mayor or the department or division head. 
(3)  The preceding provision shall not apply to swimming pool personnel or temporary, seasonal or per diem personnel. Refusal on the part of an employee to work on a holiday when requested to do so shall constitute a forfeiture of all benefits of holiday pay under this section. Failure of an employee to work on the scheduled work day preceding and the scheduled work day succeeding the holiday, unless excused by the Mayor or department or division head, or unless on vacation, shall constitute a forfeiture of all benefits of holiday pay under this section. 
(b)  No employee shall receive the benefit of the provisions of this section in more than one employment capacity with the City. 
(c)  No part time or seasonal employee will receive holiday pay. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.05 - Vacations. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 2014, full time employees shall accrue vacation time, as set forth in the schedule below, unless otherwise agreed to by contract. An increase in accrual rate due to increase in longevity will be implemented in the next full pay period following the anniversary date. The Finance Director is hereby authorized to account for the hourly accumulation of earned vacation time on the bi-weekly payroll check of all City employees entitled to vacation time. 
(1)  More than 30 but less than 40-hour employees. Employees who work less than a 40-hour week shall accrue vacation hours pro-rated, on the basis of a 40-hour week. 
(b)  Effective January 1, 2014, unless otherwise agreed by contract, no employee shall be entitled to accumulate more than three weeks of vacation time. Any vacation time accumulated in excess of such limit shall be forfeited if not used by the employee by December 31 of each year.

(b)  Effective January 1, 2014, unless otherwise agreed by contract, no employee shall be entitled to accumulate more than three weeks of vacation time. Any vacation time accumulated in excess of such limit shall be forfeited if not used by the employee by December 31 of each year. 
(c)  Effective January 1, 2014, unless otherwise agreed by contract, all employees that have accumulated vacation time in excess of three weeks shall be permitted to sell back to the City any accrued time in excess of three weeks by November 30 of each year. The employee shall receive a one-time payment from the City in the first regular pay date in December. No employee will be paid more than three weeks of time under this provision unless approved by both the Mayor and Director of Finance. Any accrued time in excess of three weeks that an employee does not sell back or use prior to December 31 shall be forfeited. 
(d)  When an employee resigns, retires or dies, salary payments in lieu of unused vacation allowance shall be granted in accordance with the schedule set forth above, provided the employee is leaving in good standing and has given two weeks' notice of the separation, where applicable: 
(1)  Any employee who has less than one year of service shall not be entitled to a salary payment in lieu of vacation. 
(e)  Full time years of service accumulated by any employee in one department or division shall be credited to such employee who transfers to another department or division for purposes of computation of vacation time. 
(f)  No employee of the City shall receive the benefit of the provisions of this section in more than one employment capacity with the City. 
(g)  The period of vacation shall be designated by the Mayor or the appropriate department or division head, or in the case of employees of Council, by Council. 
(h)  Effective January 1, 2014, no employee of the City shall be permitted to perform work for the City, in any capacity, while simultaneously receiving vacation pay. 
(i)  No part-time or seasonal employee will receive vacation pay. 
(j)  Any employee who becomes an employee of the City of Bay Village in a position of Director or Assistant Director after being employed by another political subdivision shall for the purposes of computation of vacation time be credited with the total years of his prior service with such political subdivision. The maximum vacation allowance for such an employee may not exceed four weeks for their first year of employment with the City of Bay Village and shall increase by one week for each year of continued service until the employee meets the vacation schedule in Section 151.06(a). 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.06 - Health insurance. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 2010, the City shall pay the cost of health insurance determined by the Plan adopted annually by the City of Bay Village. 
(b)  An election to participate in the group shall be made only at such times as permitted by the insurance carrier. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.061 - Health insurance eligibility. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 2012, the City will provide health, dental, vision and hearing insurance to eligible employees, in accordance with state and federal law. The employee's share of the cost of such benefits shall be determined annually by the City, unless otherwise agreed by contract. 
(b)  Eligible employees may receive family or employee only coverage per state and/or federal law and in accordance with the terms of the City of Bay Village's Health Plan. 
(c)  In lieu of employer sponsored health insurance an opt-out provision is offered as long as proof of coverage from another source is provided to the City, provided that such coverage was not purchased through a public health insurance exchange/marketplace. An employee who elects the opt-out will receive $100.00 per month in lieu of employee-only coverage or $250.00 per month in lieu of family coverage. 
(d)  Health insurance and the opt-out provision will only be offered to employees required to be offered health insurance under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and related regulations. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.07 - Physical examinations. 
(a)  Every new employee of the City, except seasonal employees, shall submit to a physical examination, if necessary to the performance of their job duties. 
(b)  After a period of illness which requires any employee to be absent from his employment for ten consecutive working days or more, the Mayor may require the employee to submit to a physical examination prior to being returned to employment. 
(c)  Any employee who refuses to undergo such physical examinations as required in subsections (a) through (b) hereof, may be subject to discharge from his employment by the City. 
(d)  The Mayor shall designate the person who is to perform such physical examinations, and the expenditure of the City funds from the correct account is hereby authorized. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.08 - Sick leave. 
(a)  Every full-time employee shall be entitled for each completed 80 hours of compensated service to sick leave of 4.6 hours with pay. Such employees may use sick leave, upon approval of the responsible administrative officer of the employing department, for absence due to personal illness, pregnancy, injury, exposure to contagious disease which could be communicated to other employees, and to illness, injury, or death as set forth in the Employee Handbook. Said Employee Handbook is incorporated herein and made a part hereof as if fully rewritten herein. For the purpose of this section: 
(1)  Department heads (excepting the Director of Law) and division chiefs shall be considered to have a work week of 40 hours; and 
(2)  "Completed compensated service" shall include paid holiday time, paid vacation time and paid sick time. 
(b)  Unused sick leave shall be cumulative without limit. When sick leave is used, it shall be deducted from the employee's credit on the basis of one hour for every one hour of absence from previously scheduled work. There will be no reduction of sick leave time when an employee is absent due to job related injury and that employee has entered into a wage continuation agreement with the City. 
(c)  Any employee who, without resigning or retiring, transfers from one department of the City to another department of the City shall be credited with the unused balance of his accumulated sick leave. 
(d)  The responsible administrative officer of the employing department may require an employee to furnish a satisfactory written, signed statement to justify the use of sick leave. If medical attention is required, a certificate stating the nature of the illness from a licensed physician may be required to justify the use of sick leave. Falsification of either a written, signed statement or a physician's certificate shall be grounds for disciplinary action, including dismissal. No sick leave shall be granted an employee upon or after his retirement or termination of employment. 
(e)  Payment at resignation, retirement or death. 
(1)  Each employee with ten or more years of service with the City shall receive payment of his or her accrued but unused sick leave based on his or her rate of pay at resignation, retirement or death at the following schedule: 
Twenty-five percent after ten years of service 
Forty percent after 15 years of service 
Fifty percent after 20 years of service 
up to a maximum payment of 50 percent of the employee's annual compensation, which payment shall be in full settlement of any and all accumulated sick leave. In the event of death, such payment shall be made to the surviving spouse, or if there is no surviving spouse, to the employee's estate. Employees who are discharged for cause forfeit all rights to payment under this subsection. 
(2)  Employees laid off for more than one year will receive accumulated sick leave based upon the last day worked and paid in accordance with the above after lapse of one year if not recalled. 
(f)  The following circumstances will control the use of "sick leave" time for all employees of the City of Bay Village: 
(1)  Illness of employee: All regularly scheduled working hours. 
(2)  Death of employee's: Son-in-law, daughter-in-law, or other relatives at the discretion of the respective department director. Sufficient time to attend funeral if scheduled to work, four hours maximum time. 
(3)  Illness requiring hospitalization of: Spouse, child, mother, father, brother, sister, and any other relative living in the employee's household. 
A.  Days of admittance to and discharge from hospital. 
B.  Day of surgery, including child birth. 
C.  Time certified as "critical" by attending physician. 
(4)  Sudden illness or injury: To anyone living in the employee's household. Sufficient time to make temporary arrangements, but no more than four hours. 
(g)  The following circumstances shall control "bereavement leave" for all employees of the City of Bay Village, which excused leave shall not be charged against accumulated but unused sick leave time and for which the employee shall be compensated as though present in his or her employment with the City. 
(1)  Death of employee's: Employee's spouse, children, step-children, parents, parents-in-law, siblings and/or other relative living in the employee's household. 
Scheduled working hours from time of death through and including day of funeral or memorial services. 
(2)  Death of employee's: Employee's siblings-in-law, grandparents, grandchildren, aunt, uncle and spouses grandparents, grandchildren, aunt and uncle. Day of funeral or memorial services if scheduled to work. 
(i)  For the purpose of administering the provisions of this section the following procedures shall be followed: 
(1)  The Director of Finance shall establish for each employee and each department a sick leave time account. 
(2)  Charges against the sum of such accumulated but unused sick leave time shall be made of one hour for every one hour of absence during regularly scheduled working hours. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.09 - Paid time off. 
(a)  Permanent part-time employees compensated on an hourly basis shall earn paid time off at a rate of .0575 hours earned per hour worked, per pay period. When paid time off is used, it shall be deducted from the employee's credit on the basis of one hour for every one hour absence from scheduled work. 
(b)  Paid time off may be used when an employee requests scheduled time off upon a 24-hour advance notice by the employee and the approval of the employee's supervisor. Paid time off may be taken with less than a 24-hour advance notice at the employee's supervisor's discretion. 
(c)  The maximum amount of paid time off an employee can use in one calendar year is 120 hours. In the event an employee is on an approved Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) absence, any amount of accrued paid time off can be used during the length of the approved FMLA absence. 
(d)  If PTO is used for an illness or injury refer to Section 151.08-Sick Leave. This article also applies to unused PTO in the event of resignation, retirement or death. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.091 - Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA). 
    Family Medical Leave shall be granted and administered in accordance with applicable Federal and State laws. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.10 - Longevity. 
(a)  Effective January 1, 2001, there shall be paid to all non-elected regular full-time employees, excluding employees covered under separate labor contract, additional compensation based on their years of service, at the rate of $100.00 per year of service, after completion of five years, to a maximum of $3,000.00. 
(b)  For new hires after January 1, 2016 the following amendment shall apply: full-time employees shall receive longevity payments after five years of continuous full-time employment in the following table: 
5-9 years $500.00 each year 
10-14 years $1,000.00 each year 
15-19 years $1,500.00 each year 
20-24 years $2,000.00 each year 
25 years and above $2,500.00 each year 
(c)  The calculation of "years of service" shall begin on the anniversary date of the employee's original date of hire by the City. 
(d)  No individual employed by the City in more than one capacity shall be entitled to the benefits of this compensation in other than his primary department. 
(e)  Termination of employment, for any reason, either voluntary or involuntary, shall terminate all rights and accrued benefits and eligibility under this section, except that those retiring shall be paid a pro-rated amount at time of retirement. Any employee who retires and is hired full-time by another department of the City shall accrue benefits hereunder as if the employee were a new employee and prior service with the City shall not be counted. 
(f)  For the purpose of determining the eligibility for longevity only, "full-time" shall be defined as an employee working 35 hours or more each week. The Mayor shall receive longevity only if specifically provided for in the compensation ordinance for the term in question. 
(g)  The amounts due hereunder shall be paid only to full-time employees, as defined in Section 151.10(e), on the first regular pay date in December. 
(h)  In addition to the cash payments provided for in this chapter, the Mayor is authorized to present Service Award Pins to those full-time or part-time employees, members of boards and commissions, and such other persons as the Mayor may designate from time to time, whether paid or unpaid, who have at least five years' service with the City. 
(i)  Part-time and seasonal employees shall not be eligible for longevity compensation hereunder. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.11 - Overtime compensation. 
(a)  Salaried/exempt employees shall not be paid overtime for hours worked in excess of 40 in workweek, unless otherwise agreed by contract. 
(b)  Hourly/non-exempt employees shall receive overtime for hours worked in excess of 40 in a workweek. 
(c)  No employee who serves the City in more than one capacity may combine his total work hours for the calendar week for the purposes of overtime computation, but each position work hours are to be counted separately. 
(d)  Holiday, vacation and sick leave time shall be included in the computation of overtime hours for the calendar week. 
(e)  Payment of overtime compensation (except that for the Department of Public Safety) shall be made on the first regular payday occurring after the hours have been worked. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.12 - Life insurance. 
    The City shall pay the cost of group term life and accidental death and dismemberment insurance up to a maximum benefit of $50,000.00 for employees who work 30 hours or more in a given workweek, elect to participate, and are acceptable to the insurance company. However, once obtaining the age of 65 said life insurance will be reduced to $32,500.00 and once obtaining the age of 70 said life insurance will be reduced to $25,000.00. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.13 - Privacy act rules. 
    The Mayor is hereby authorized to adopt such written rules and regulations as may be necessary for the purpose of interpreting and enforcing the Ohio Privacy Act, being Ohio R.C. 1347.01 et seq. Such rules and regulations shall not conflict with or waive any privileges as provided by this City's Charter or ordinances. Such rules and regulations shall be on file with the City, and all parties affected shall be advised of their contents. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.14 - Surety bonds. 
    The surety bonds covering the employees of the City shall be as follows: 
(a)  Mayor-$15,000.00 public official bond for term of office. 
(b)  Director of Finance-$50,000.00 public official bond for an indefinite term. 
(c)  All other City employees-$25,000.00 honesty blanket position bond. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.15 - Equal employment opportunity policies. 
(a)  Council formally declares that the City shall provide equal employment opportunities (EEO) to all employees and applicants for employment without regard to sex, race, color, religion, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, national origin, age, genetic information, disability or handicap (except where age or handicap would be an obvious and bona fide obstacle to expected and required job performance), genetic information, marital status, amnesty status as a covered veteran or pregnancy in accordance with applicable federal, state and local laws. The City shall comply with a all applicable state and local laws governing non-discrimination in the employment in every location or facility. This policy applies to all terms and conditions of employment, including but not limited to recruiting, hiring, placement, promotion, termination, layoff, recall, transfer, leaves of absence, compensation and training. 
(b)  Artificial barriers of personal attitudes and customs cannot be permitted to have effect in matters of personnel practices. 
(c)  The City expressly prohibits any form of unlawful employee harassment based on sex, race, color, religion, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, national origin, age genetic information, disability, veteran status or pregnancy. Improper interference with the ability of the City's employees to perform their expected job duties is absolutely not tolerated. 
(d)  The Director of Finance, by direction of the Mayor, will have overall responsibility for the implementation of this policy. With the cooperation of appropriate personnel, the Director of Finance will conduct periodic reviews to determine whether or not this policy is being adhered to. Reports of these reviews will be the basis for appropriate action to correct deficiencies. 
(e)  When outside sources of recruitment are used they shall be informed that the City is an Equal Opportunity Employer and that legal advertisements for bids include the wording, "AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY EMPLOYER" and that Equal Opportunity clauses be included in all major single purchase orders, leases and contracts. 
(f)  The Clerk of Council is hereby directed to post, or have posted, a copy of this resolution on all departmental bulletin boards as well as provide a copy of this resolution to all employees of the City. 
( Ord. No. 16-44 ,  1, 6-20-2016) 
151.16 - Compensation payment. 
(a)  Payment dates shall be: 
(1)  For hourly employees. On February 14, 1975, and every other Friday thereafter, all hourly paid employees shall be paid for all hours worked during the previous two weeks. 
(2)  For salaried employees and elected officials. All salaried employees and elected officials shall receive their appropriate annual compensation on a bi-weekly basis, payment to be made on the same dates as payment is made to hourly personnel. The Director of Finance shall adjust the pay period rate so that in each calendar year the precise annual compensation is paid regardless of the number of bi-weekly payment dates during the year. 
(c)  Should any payment date referred to herein fall on a holiday, payment shall be made on the last working day preceding such holiday.
