Any unattended motor vehicles found standing or parked in a fire lane may be impounded in a manner and subject to the penalties and charges set forth in Chapter 307. 
(Ord. 63-10. Passed 2-18-63.) 
1721.05 - Removal of obstructions. 
    Obstructions, other than motor vehicles, found in fire lanes shall be removed by the owner, occupant or other person in charge of the premises, within three days after written notice of removal. Upon failure to comply with such notice the City may cause the obstruction to be removed and the owner, occupant or other person in charge of the premises shall pay the cost of such removal. 
(Ord. 63-10. Passed 2-18-63.) 
1721.06 - Notice and appeal. 
    Whenever the Chief of the Division of Fire designates a fire lane, written notice thereof shall be given to the owner, occupant or person in charge of the premises. Such designation may be appealed within ten days by filing a written objection to such designation with the Fire Chief. The appeal shall be heard by the members of Council, a majority of whom may affirm, disaffirm or modify the designation and whose decision shall be final. 
(Ord. 63-10. Passed 2-18-63.) 
1721.07 - Enforcement. 
    The powers conferred upon the Division of Fire and the Division of Police in Section 515.05 of the General Offenses Code shall apply to the provisions of this chapter regarding fire lanes. 
(Ord. 72-110. Passed 7-17-72.) 
1721.99 - Penalty; waiver. 
(a)  Any person who is cited for a violation of this chapter for parking or leaving standing an unattended motor vehicle, in addition to the impounding provisions and charges provided by Section 1721.04, shall be subject to the penalties and waiver provisions of Section 341.99 of the Traffic Code, all of which are incorporated by reference. (Ord. 78-34. Passed 3-20-78.) 
(b)  Except as provided in subsection (a) hereof, any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or fails to comply with any order made hereunder, shall severally for each and every such violation or noncompliance respectively be guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day of such violation or failure to comply shall constitute a separate offense. The imposition of a fine or penalty shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and such violations shall be remedied. 
(Ord. 85-40. Passed 4-15-85.) 
Chapter 1723 - WESTSHORE REGIONAL COMMUNITY EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAM 

1723.01 - Established. 
    This chapter shall be identified as the "Westshore Regional Community Emergency Response Team" (Hereafter WSC). 
(a)  General definitions. 
(1)  As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or the context otherwise requires, The WSC shall hereinafter serve as a regionally sponsored volunteer organization as a unit of the City of North Olmsted Department of Public Safety and the Westshore Council of Governments through the fire chief or their designee. The organization and structure of the WSC shall substantially comply with the organization and structure recommended by FEMA, the State of Ohio, Cuyahoga County EMA, and be compatible with the National Incident Management System. 
(2)  Westshore Council of Governments or Westshore Council of Government city/cities shall refer to the cities of Bay Village, Fairview Park, Lakewood, North Olmsted, Rocky River, and Westlake. 
(b)  Volunteer status. 
(1)  All WSC members shall serve as volunteers only. 
(2)  WSC members shall not seek or accept any monetary compensation of any kind for volunteer service, shall acknowledge and agree that any loss or injury incurred during service shall be solely at the risk of the volunteer, waive any and all claims for him/herself, his/her heirs and assigns, and agree to hold harmless the City of Bay Village, Ohio, its employees and agents for any such loss or injury as well as the Westshore Council of Governments and its employees and agents, provided that such indemnity shall not be effective for damages that result from negligent or intentional acts of the City or the Westshore Council of Governments, their employees or agents. 
(c)  Membership/identification cards. Any person 18 years of age or older who is a resident of a Westshore Council of Governments city or is a resident in a city contiguous to a Westshore city may volunteer to become a member of the WSC if they meet all of the following requirements: 
(1)  Submit a completed application for WSC membership. 
(2)  Complete required FEMA training. 
(3)  Abide by and fulfill membership requirements defined in the WSC Guidelines. 
(4)  Submit to a background check. 
A.  Every WSC applicant shall submit to a background check conducted by the appropriate representative of a Westshore city police department. 
B.  Only upon successful completion thereof as per the WSC Guidelines, the volunteer shall be issued a WSC identification card, which he/she may retain during his/her continued active membership and good behavior. 
C.  The identification card is and remains at all times the property of the WSC. 
(5)  At such time as a volunteer leaves the organization for any reason or is expelled or has his/her membership terminated, he/she agrees to return the identification card to the WSC coordinator forthwith. 
(d)  Termination. Westshore safety directors or their designees may, at their discretion, terminate any volunteer from the WSC organization. 
(e)  WSC guidelines. The WSC shall keep up to date such Guidelines necessary for the governance and efficient operation of the WSC. 
(f)  WSC activation. 
(1)  The WSC may be activated for the purposes of assisting public safety forces by the Municipal Safety Authority. The Municipal Safety Authority shall be the Mayor, the Director of Public Safety, the Fire Chief, or the Police Chief. 
(2)  As a regional team under the Westshore Council of Governments, the Municipal Safety Authorities of any Westshore Council of Governments city may also activate the WSC. 
(g)  Administration representation. A fire chief representing the Westshore Council of Governments or their designee shall attend all regularly scheduled WSC Advisory Committee meetings, shall represent all Westshore Council of Government cities at such meetings, and shall report to the Westshore fire chiefs and mayors on the activities, needs, and other relevant matters concerning the WSC. 
(h)  Funding and audits. 
(1)  As a Westshore Council of Governments sponsored organization, the WSC is designated as a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization. 
(2)  Through the Westshore fire chiefs, the WSC may apply for funding from Westshore city councils in the same manner as other departments subject to the rules and regulations governing all municipal funds and further subject to the review, audit and oversight of the Westshore Council of Governments fiscal officer. 
(3)  All books and records of the WSC shall be made available to all Westshore directors of finance and council finance committees in conjunction with the budgetary process. 
(4)  No funds of the organization shall be used for any purpose other than the training and retention of volunteers, and the purchase and maintenance of equipment, supplies, disaster preparedness materials, and fundraising supplies necessary to fulfill the stated purpose(s) of the WSC. 
(5)  No WSC funds shall be used for or paid to any person or persons serving as a volunteer in the WSC with the exception of authorized reimbursements. 
(i)  WSC equipment. 
(1)  All WSC equipment and supplies are and remains the property of the WSC and Westshore Council of Governments. 
(2)  Equipment issued to WSC members including but not limited to CERT kits, shirts, hats, and identification cards are and remains the property of the WSC and the Westshore Council of Governments. 
(3)  At such time as a volunteer leaves the organization for any reason or is expelled or has his/her membership terminated, he/she agrees to return the identification card to the WSC coordinator forthwith. 
(j)  Donations. 
(1)  As a 501(c)(3) under the Westshore Council of Governments, the WSC may accept donations to the WSC from private sources including but not limited to private citizens, corporations, non-governmental organizations (NGOs), charitable non-profit corporations, and other similar entities. 
(2)  Donations may be in cash or in kind. 
(3)  The WSC coordinator or his/her designee, upon request, will issue a charitable donation receipt to any donor. 
(k)  Penalties. Any person who violates provisions of Chapter 1729(i) and fails to return to the WSC an identification card, CERT kit, and/or other equipment issued to him/her will be subject to a replacement fee, which will be determined by the WSC coordinator. 
(Ord. 13-1. Passed 1-14-13.)
